We are not withdrawing our troops, irrespective of any UN decision; but, by the way, people of Australia, we're not going to tell you about it. We will not make this comment publicly.' What an absolute indictment of this government. We, the Labor Party, accuse the government of keeping the people of Australia in the dark. And this revelation on Channel 9 tonight totally vindicates the position of the Labor Party in this respect.

How stupid does the government think the people of Australia are? Does the government seriously think that people will believe, after the predeployment of 2,000 troops, that if the United Nations process works very smoothly and things go according to plan those troops will be withdrawn or that the government has had a Damascan revelation about internationalism through the processes of the United Nationsâ`Let us hope there is peace' et ceteraâwhen the Minister for Foreign Affairs admitted in October last year in a private conversation that this government had no intention whatsoever of withdrawing those troops if the UN processes broke down but he could not say it publicly?

I think that speaks volumes. That says to the Australian people something that they have known for a long time in relation to this issueâthat you cannot trust this government. They are not coming clean. They are not telling the truth to the Australian people. You just have to talk to people on the street to realise they know this. Here we have, in October last year, an admission from the foreign affairs minister, Mr Downer, that there has never been any intention to withdraw the troops, irrespective of any UN decision. I think that is absolutely startling and very revealing information. It will simply add to the distrust the people of Australia already have of the sycophantic behaviour of the government towards the United States.
I noticed that the Prime Minister quite recently talked about Vietnam in relation to this issue. In fact, in an article in the Weekend Australian of Saturday, 1 February 2003, he said:

quote.para: I think the arguments here are even more compelling than they were in relation to Vietnam.

speech.para: Obviously we have a Prime Minister who still believes that the action in Vietnam was correct. I do not meet anybody these days who thinks that the action in Vietnam was correctânobodyâbut the Prime Minister says `even more compelling than Vietnam'. What an indictment that is. The government is not putting the interests of Australians first. Instead, Australia's national interest is coming secondâlook at the obsequious behaviour of the government towards George W. Bushâto George W. Bush's obsession with destroying Saddam Hussein.

After the disastrous events of September 11, we all said that a link between al-Qaeda and Iraq had to be found to prove a clear and present danger there. There has been no evidence to date of such a link. What the American government sought to do, however, was distort the issue in relation to those tragic events of September 11 by trying to involve Saddam Hussein. I want to put on the record that nobody here in this parliament thinks that Saddam Hussein is anything other than a tyrant and a thugânobody here thinks anything other than that. Obviously the Iraqi people would be far better off without Saddam Hussein, but the same could be said, as Senator Lees said, about many governments across the world.

Many people would argue that in fact North Korea poses a greater threat to the world than Iraq. Not only is North Korea known to have nuclear capability but it has withdrawn from the nuclear non-proliferation treaty and has threatened to resume its nuclear program. What has the response of the Bush administration been to North Korea? Far less hawkish than it has been towards Iraq. If ever there were a country that might merit the sort of argument put forward in relation to Iraq, North Korea would be streets ahead. It has made active threats and it has withdrawn from the treaty.

It is no wonder that people across the world, including in Australia, are legitimately asking, `Why Iraq?' Why Iraq? Why has the Iraqi regime under Hussein been elevated to the position of public enemy No. 1?' I have to disagree with the previous speaker; I believe that a lot of it has to do with Iraq having huge oilfields and with the fact that the US currently consumes around 25 per cent of the world's oil supplies. We know that the United States Department of Energy announced recently that by 2025 US oil imports will be around 70 per cent of total US domestic demand, up from 55 per cent two years ago. International oilfields are becoming increasingly depleted, and there is an increased likelihood that in the future world oil supplies will be dependent on Gulf oil. We also know that there are many people in the Bush administration who advocate the argument that resource or energy security is a primary mission for the US military. That the Bush administration believes its strategic and economic interests will benefit from a regime change in Iraq to a government more supportive of American interests is patently clear. We also know that one of the reasons that President Bush has been talking up war in Iraq for a long time is to shore up domestic support for the Republican Party in the recent congressional elections. I have to say that that bit of wedge politics paid off big time. The White House is now using the threat of war against Iraq as a convenient way of distracting the American people from any concerns about the faltering state of the United States economy.

The decision by the Prime Minister to deploy Australian troops to the Gulf region in January was the wrong decision. We now know that when those troops went off in January this government had no intention whatsoever of bringing them back. I bring the Senate back to the startling admission today on Channel 9 that Alexander Downer indicated to the New Zealand High Commissioner in October last year that, if the UN process broke down, Australia was not in a position to withdraw ships, troops or presence in the Gulf but that this was not a point that could be made publicly. I ask the government to respond, perhaps through its next speaker, as to whether this statement is in fact correct. I ask the government to explain to the Australian people why it did not say that in October last year and why it continues to perpetuate this fiction that the situation is not QED.

talk.start.para: âLike many, I came to parliament this week acutely aware of my responsibilities as an elected representative of South Australians. Surveys and polls over the last few months, including today, have demonstrated that the vast majority of Australians are opposed to Australia's involvement in a US-led war against Iraq. Today I speak together with those Australians. I share their deep concerns and I share the many, many questions that they and others in this chamber have.

speech.para: I want to make two things very clear from the outset. Firstly, I deplore the dictatorship of Saddam Hussein and I am appalled by the atrocities that have been committed in the name of that dictatorship. I want the Iraqi people to be democratically governed and to have their fundamental human rights respected. I also want the Iraqi peopleâas I want the people of Zimbabwe, North Korea, China, Tibet and Burma, among othersâto be protected from human rights abuses and to have the opportunity to freely elect their political representatives. Secondly, I am unequivocally opposed to the development, storage and use of weapons of mass destructionâwhether by India, Pakistan, Iraq, France, Russia or indeed the United States of America. Yet despite my very strong feelings on these issues I do not support Australia's involvement in military action against Iraq.

War is not just another strategy to achieve desired ends. War is a desperate measure. Only the most exceptional circumstances can ever justify the killing of other human beings. Not only must war be eminently justified but its objectives must be clear and precise. The objectives of military action against Iraq are anything but clear at this stage. The reasons given by Tony Blair, George W. Bush and, indeed, our own Prime Minister for such military action do not assist us. In fact, they simply raise more questions. These are questions they have failed to answer and questions that I know many Australians would like the Prime Minister to address. It is disappointing that we did not have question time today as that would have enabled us to ask the government some of these questions. In the absence of question time, I am going to put on notice and put on the public record a number of the questions that we have.

We know that Iraq has consistently failed to meet its obligations relating to disarmament and weapons inspections following the Gulf War. Of course it is vitally important to ensure that Iraq complies with these obligations. But, if the war is about forcing Iraq to comply with international law, why are we contemplating illegal military action to achieve this compliance? It simply does not make sense to break the law, in this case, in order to enforce it. Nor does it make sense to abandon the procedures of the United Nations in order to enforce the resolutions of the United Nations. The inconsistencyâindeed, the hypocrisyâof this was illustrated in the recent State of the Union address given by President Bush. The President accused Iraq of being in contempt of the United Nations. He then went on to make it clear that the United States would not depend on the decisions of others.

We do not need to rely on the words of President Bush to understand the attitude of the United States towards international law on occasions. If the United States is so committed to international law, as outlined by President Bush, then how does it explain the imposition of embargoes on the supply of food and medicine to Cuba when such embargoes have been repeatedly condemned by UN resolutions and described as `serious violation of international law'? The United States has also ignored international law, specifically the Convention on the Rights of the Child and the Beijing rules, when it has executed people who were under the age of 18 when they committed a crime. What legal or moral authority does the United States have to make other countries comply with their international obligations when this is its own track record?

The Prime Minister has consistently stated that the purpose of any proposed war would be to address the threat posed by Iraq's weapons of mass destruction. If this is the purpose, then why are we not also going to war against North Korea? Many nations around this world have weapons of mass destruction. The United States, as we know, has an abundance of such weapons. For a nation which professes such a strong opposition to weapons of mass destruction, it is interesting to note that the US remains the only nation which has ever resorted to the use of nuclear weapons during military warfare. It also refuses to sign the protocol to the biological weapons convention.

Yet the fundamental distinction that is relied upon is that weapons of mass destruction in the hands of so-called rogue states, which has been referred to repeatedly today, present a particular threat to international security. There is no doubt that Iraq is a rogue state. What is not clear, however, is what exactly defines a rogue state and why we are not pursuing military action against other rogue states that possess weapons of mass destruction. If a rogue state is one which is not democratically governed, then what about North Korea? If it is a state in which human rights abuses occur, then what about China? How does the United Kingdom justify the exportation of key nuclear weapons-grade material to Iran? If the US and the UK are so opposed to weapons of mass destruction, why is it that neither country will rule out the use of nuclear weapons in military action against Iraq? If the war is really about Iraq's weapons of mass destruction program, why has President Bush said that the voluntary exile of Saddam Hussein would be one way to prevent the war?

This brings me to the issue of regime change. There are many reasons to abhor the regime of Saddam Hussein and to seek an end to the suffering of the Iraqi people under that regime. We have all heard the stories of torture and murder. They appal us all. The stories that we hear appal me; they anger me; they grieve me. Yet while the United States and Australia condemned these practices in Iraq, neither country was prepared to support the optional protocol to the convention against torture. If the purpose of the war is really to topple a cruel and undemocratic dictatorship, then why aren't we also going to war against Zimbabwe? The Prime Minister will not even stop the Australian cricket team from playing in Zimbabwe as a sign of our opposition to that regime; yet he will risk the lives of Australians to put an end to Saddam Hussein's dictatorship.

If the war is to save the Iraqi people, why does Washington intend to adopt a strategy in which 800 missiles could be launched on Baghdad, where almost five million Iraqis live? If the purpose of this war is to achieve regime change, what exactly are we hoping to change the regime to? How will it work? What is the post war assistance that we are going to offer Iraq? None, according to our Prime Minister, who told us last week that Australia would not be involved in any such rebuilding process.

It appears that none of the reasons given for this war really stacks up, which begs the question: what is the real underlying motivation for this war? Some suggest oil; others suggest US imperialism. I am not going to speculate on those allegations, but one thing is clear: no persuasive argument has been made to justify any military action against Iraq at this stage. The Prime Minister tells us that the decision as to whether or not Australia should participate in this war weighs heavily on him. I say to the Prime Minister: this is not your burden to bear. When faced with such a grave decision, the Prime Minister should turn to the Australian people. That is what democracy is all about. That is what differentiates regimes such as that of Saddam Hussein and those of democratic governments.

It is time to change the rhetoric in this debate. It is time we stopped restricting the debate to the terms dictated by George W. Bush, our Prime Minister or even Tony Blair. Going to war against Iraq does not demonstrate leadership. It demonstrates failure. The Prime Minister risks associating his premiership with a rush to failure. War represents failure because it gives up on those things that characterise decent civilisation: negotiation, rational discussion, persuasion, the use of international goodwill and the offer of help in return for cooperation. If the combined brains of the international community cannot avoid war, we have failed desperately. John Winston Howard should have regard to another WinstonâWinston Churchill. Despite his great reputation as a wartime leader and warrior chief, despite the glory that came his way, Churchill said it best when in the fifties he said: `To jaw-jaw is better than to war-war.' He said this in Washington. Let the Prime Minister go to Washington and jaw-jaw.

We the people do not want war. We do not want to send our younger or older Australians to terrible fields of conflict to use disgusting weaponry against each other, against their fellow human beings, and to risk them returning to their homeland injured, limbless and demented by the horrors they have witnessed or coming home dead. We want people to live peacefully without the deaths of thousands, if not millions, on our conscience. We want to face the problems that we have; we do not want to create new ones. We want to write our history. We want to say sorry. We do not want to create more and more reasons for being sorry. There are no sufficient reasons for being involved in this conflict. There are no reasons to include Australians; bring the troops home. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIf we are to be honest in this debate, we must accept that Iraq is a world problem. Most Australians understand that. Iraq is a rogue stateâand Australians certainly understand that. The Saddam regime has a zero record when it comes to complying with UN demands that it disarm itself of weapons of mass destructionâand Australians understand that. Australians understand that, if he will not disarm, he will have to be disarmed. Australians understand that this is a risk and that sometimes you have to take risks to do the right thing. Sometimes you have to make a stand and that time is now. Under American leadership and in partnership with Britain and other countries, we are making a stand.

speech.para: War is an abhorrent notion, as we have heard here repeatedly today. It is to be avoided whenever there is an alternative path. But sometimes being decisive todayâ even at the risk of warâcan avoid conflict or save us a greater and more deadly conflict later. The world is trying to avoid a war today by making it clear to Saddam Hussein that his time has run out. I believe time has also run out for those who want Australians to believe that there is no such thing as a just war. Labor and Simon Crean are in grave danger of falling into this trap. In fact, they seem to want to fall into itâanother abject failure of the party that aspires to be the alternative government. So, too, are the churches, some of whose leading members have been prominent in the peace not war movement that is trying to take over our streets and apparently has taken over some of our churches. Their `no need for war' position overturns a millennium of Christian tradition and threatens to remove the moral force of the church from genuinely influencing state policy in times of conflict. Last year when he was asked if he thought Saddam was a dangerous person, the Anglican Primate of Australia, Archbishop Peter Carnley, said Saddam was `morally suspect'.

Is it merely morally suspect to wage war on your neighbours and your own people? Is it merely morally suspect to act as paymaster for suicide bombers who attack and wreck Israel? Is it merely morally suspect to seek to acquire chemical, biological, and possibly nuclear, weapons for clearly offensive purposes? Can the Anglican Primate of Australia possibly and genuinely believe this?

The Saddam regime in Iraq has played games with the world, with the UN, for 12 years, since it was evicted from Kuwait. Saddam Hussein has shown no willingness to mediate his circumstances and his demands against those of the world community. We hope the UN will, through action to enforce Iraq's compliance with resolution 1441. But if it will not, if it again allows Saddam Hussein to thumb his nose at the world and continue his oppression and weapons acquisition, then nations with sufficient moral fibre will, in my personal view, have a real job to do and they will need to do it. We want to avoid that, of course. We believe that, ultimately, the moral force of the argument presented by the Americansâand pre-eminently by President Bush in his State of the Union address to Congress last weekâwill persuade the Security Council to hold firm.

These are the facts: Saddam Hussein has a record of murderous behaviour and dangerous weapons. The United Nations must play its full role or it will have to be bypassed. Leadership has come from various sources; if the UN will not provide it, then other options, in my view, need to be considered. Leadership came from America in the Cuban missile crisis of 1962, when the United States faced down the Soviet Union. Leadership came from Britain in the Falklands in 1982, when the UK fought to regain the Falklands on behalf of the 1,800 islandersâ British subjectsâfrom the regime of the Argentine generals. Leadership again came from America on September 11, 2001, when the United States suffered direct attack by terrorists.

But the stand we are making is not one that must inevitably lead to war. It is a stand designed to avoid war, to force the opponent to back down without a fight. As the Leader of the Government in the Senate noted in his speech this afternoon, the history of the 20th century demonstrates with stark and murderous clarity the folly of trying to appease dictators. It teaches in blood how sometimes it is better to fight a small war than to wait for a big one to start. I believe that, with Iraq, the Prime Minister has shown tremendous leadership and great courage. The opposition leader has not, and that is a real shame. It is a shame on him, it is a shame on his partyâ which aspires to governmentâand it is a shame on this country. Under its present leader, the Labor Party has let this country down. It has played shrill politics where it could and should have played statesman politics.

Of course Australians are concerned about the risk that their country may find itself at war. Of course Australiansâall Australians, religious or not, and of whatever creedâ pray that the volunteer members of the Australian Defence Force in the Gulf, or on the way there, will be safe and that they will not have to go to war. The government's strategy is to avoid war. The Labor Party and other critics of the Prime Minister and his policy must understand that, because that is the reality. The Australian deployment to the region bolstersâby a measured and appropriate amount, taking into account our national interests and our military capabilitiesâthe forces deployed there or being deployed there by the United States and Britain. One reason for the deployment ahead of possible events is that personnel need to acclimatise, and equipment and in-theatre training have to be worked upâsomething else Senator Hill mentioned in his speech. The opposition leader might pretend he does not know this. His predecessor is too honest to make such a hollow pretence. Another reason for the early deployment is to put the Iraqi regime in as tight a vice as possible in order to persuade it to back down. The opposition leader may pretend he does not know this. His predecessor is too honest to do so.

President George Bush's State of the Union address last week put tremendous pressure on the Security Council to stick to its guns and insist that the Iraqi regime does what the UN says is required of it. It should eventually bring France and Germany into line. We note that Italy and Spain are already on board with Britain. The European Union really should be able to speak with one voice on so important an international issue if it expects to be taken seriously as a unified voice in world affairs. The Prime Minister's visit to Washington, New York and London next week for talks with President Bush, the UN, and the British Prime Minister is a measured response to Iraq's continued defiance of the UN. It is not about `all the way with George W. Bush'; it is about continuing to talk to the United States and its president and continuing to put forward Australia's view and to represent the Australian interest.

No-one should forget that, if the world had acted more firmly against Saddam's murderous banditry in the past, we would not today find ourselves in the position of having to contemplate the possibility of going to war. The best outcome would be for Saddam to back down. His record indicates that he will only do so if confronted by annihilation. The world should not be taken in either by Saddam's militaristic rhetoric.
Debate interrupted.

subdebate.1.para: Senator Forshaw to move on the next day of sitting:

motion.para: That the Senateâ
(a) extends its condolences to the families, relatives and friends of the persons who died in the tragic train disaster near Waterfall, New South Wales, on Friday, 31 January 2003;
(b) expresses its best wishes for a speedy recovery to those injured in the disaster; and

(c) acknowledges the dedication of the emergency services personnel and medical and hospital staff who responded to the tragedy and worked under great difficulty to rescue passengers and provide them with assistance and comfort.

subdebate.1.para: Senator Allison to move on the next day of sitting:

motion.para: That there be laid on the table, no later than 4 pm on Thursday, 6 February 2003, the submission or submissions made by the Department of Defence to the Environment Impact Assessment for a National Radioactive Waste Repository in South Australia.

subdebate.1.para: Senator Allison to move on the next day of sitting:

motion.para: That there be laid on the table, no later than 4 pm on Monday, 3 March 2003, all documents relating to the records and communications between the Department of Defence and the Department of Education, Science and Training concerning the Government's consideration of a National Radioactive Waste Repository in South Australia.

subdebate.1.para: Senator Ridgeway to move on the next day of sitting:

motion.para: That the Senateâ

(a) notes, with sadness, the passing on 27 December 2002 at the age of 67, of Prince of Wales Midpul an Elder of the Larrakia people of the Darwin region, who was an exceptional dancer, didgeridoo player, songman, and artist;

(b) pays tribute to Midpul as one of the Northern Territory's most renowned artists, who was best known outside his community for his powerful, minimalist paintings, called `Body Marks', which depicted Larrakia body designs from the ceremonies, dances and songs for which he was one of the principal custodians;

(c) notes that Midpul only began painting in 1995-96, yet his works hang in many of Australia's foremost public and private collections, including the National Gallery of Australia, the National Gallery of Victoria and the Art Gallery of NSW, and he was the recipient of the Telstra Open Painting Award at the National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Art Awards in 2001; and

(d) remembers Midpul's long struggle, along with other members of his family, to achieve land rights for the Larrakia people, including the successful land claims for Kulaluk and Kenbi, and thanks his family for their permission to refer to him by name in recognition of his outstanding achievements as an artist and community leader.

subdebate.1.para: Senator Ridgeway to move on the next day of sitting:

motion.para: That the Senateâ

(a) pays tribute to Mr Albert Namatjira as the first Indigenous professional artist in Australia, who was born one hundred years ago and died in 1959, after achieving national and international acclaim for his exceptional ability as an artist;
(b) acknowledges that Namatjira:
(i) adapted Western-style painting to express his cultural knowledge and the strength of his connection to his traditional country, and

(ii) is now regarded as a national treasure in recognition of the cultural legacy he has left all Australians, as well as the inspiration he is to the generations of Indigenous artists who have followed in his footsteps;
(c) recognises that:

(i) the legal protection of Namatjira's works provided by the Copyright Act 1968 will expire in 2009, bringing to an end the ability of the copyright owner to exercise an exclusive right to use and reproduce his works, or to allow others to do so in return for a financial benefit; and

(ii) the Public Trustee of the Northern Territory Government authorised the sale of Namatjira's copyright to Legend Press in 1983, thereby ending the ability of the descendents of Namatjira to benefit from on-going income from the reproduction of his works; and
(d) calls on the Government to:

(i) enter into discussions with the Northern Territory Government to buy back the copyright in Namatjira's works so that exclusive control of the use and reproduction of his works is restored to his descendents, as well as the receipt of all financial benefits that result from the use and reproduction of his works under copyright protection, and

(ii) in recognition of the contribution Namatjira has made to the development of Australia's cultural identity and the need to protect his legacy for future generations, explore all relevant legal and other measures that will provide ongoing protection of the Namatjira name and his reputation and standing as one of our pre-eminent artists.

talk.start.para: (Senator Cook)âOrder! It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:

motion.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talker.name: Troeth, Sen Judith
Senator TROETH
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: â I rise firstly to extend sincere sympathy to the residents of Canberra, who have suffered such severe deprivation and loss in the recent bushfires. For the residents of Victoria, while the loss of life has not been an issue, the loss of property and the issue of national heritage, in some instances going up in flames, is something that I sympathise with greatly. I wish to extend my sincere condolences to them.

speech.para: However, at a time when we have not had the best summer season in the world, nor have trade and other seasonal conditions been favouring farmers, I would like to look to the future. In this instance, I would like to examine the report of the Sex Discrimination Unit of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, which last year handed down its blueprint for a national paid maternity leave scheme.

I welcome this proposal, as it contains some important considerations for the future of Australian families. I would like to bring the report to the attention of all senators. The proposal is entitled A time to value. In its recommendations, the scheme is to be Commonwealth government funded, with employers encouraged to top up the payment through enterprise bargaining. Women in full-time, part-time or casual work for 40 out of the past 52 weeks are to be eligible. There will be a 14-week minimum entitlement of the federal minimum wage of $431 per week or the equivalent of the recipient's previous weekly earnings from all jobs, whichever is the lesser amount.

Women receiving paid maternity leave will not be able to claim baby bonus, maternity allowance or family tax benefit. I would also like to point out that 85,000 women annually are expected to receive paid maternity leave. The estimated cost to the Commonwealth government of paid maternity leave would be $460 million gross, and that would be offset by the cost of baby bonus, maternity allowance or family tax benefit. The cost of the scheme is calculated to be $213 million for 2003-04.

Australia is one of only two OECD countries that do not have a system of paid maternity leave. At the heart of the proposal is the changing face of the Australian family, the combination of commitments for working mothers and the overarching need for newborn babies to be with their mothers, rather than separated through financial necessity. Information for the proposal was collected through consultation with a wide range of employer and employee groups, unions, women's organisations and community organisations in all states. The report was based on the input from those groups, who represent the views of the majority of Australian women. Given the level of consultation, and the primary role of the Howard coalition government in the preservation and protection of families, I would like to see my government consider the proposal in the context of work and family policy settings.

talk.start.para: âYou might have to talk to Nick Minchin about that.

âI will be, Senator Crossin. Juggling work and family responsibilities can weigh heavily on men and women alike, but it can prove particularly difficult for working mothers. The report contends that it is part of the broader issue of work and life balance. The proposal reflects accounts of women who, after their husbands have lost their jobs, have, in order to breastfeed, returned to work with a two-week-old under the counter. You would hope that in the Australia of 2003 that prospect would not have to be contemplated. Other women report that they do not have enough leave or money saved up to have another child. You would hope that such contemplations would not play a part in the sort of family planning that I would like to see. Others, who deferred motherhood due to financial concerns, discovered that it was biologically too late to start a family.

speech.para: The proposal on paid maternity leave, as put forward by the unit, takes into account the undeniable change in today's family structure. This has been attributed to `irreversible global factors' as well as the incorporated cost of living, job uncertainty, high divorce rates and the changed expectations of men and women. The proposal also asserts that government family policy must evolve and modify to suit the changes to the overall family and social environment.

The government has already demonstrated its commitment to Australian families. In accordance with that commitment, I would like to look seriously at the recommendations laid out in the report and in the perspective of the changed structure of the modern family. This proposal tables a fundamental question: `Is the concept of modern family, and a woman's choice to have a child, a right or a privilege?' The proposal concludes that the scheme will be of most benefit to women in low-pay, low-skill jobs with limited bargaining power. As such, almost half of the recipients of the proposed paid maternity leave scheme would receive the equivalent of full wage replacement for up to 14 weeks.

This report may not as yet be the archetypical response to the issue of paid maternity leave, and it acknowledges that implementation is not a panacea. I am sure that there will be sufficient debate and further consultation required before policy on this issue is determined. I would like to think that the government, and the Senate in particular, would contemplate this proposal based on the current considerations to family benefit, but in that wider context of work and family policy. The document contains vital considerations of national importance and I urge all senators to review its recommendations.

As a Victorian senator, a parent of five and a grandparent of three, I can reflect on my own experiences as a working mother. I would like to think that a government view on family and work policy had changed sufficiently over the last 20 to 25 years and that we could take further considerations into account. I would like to point out that it is not a solution to the problem of the fertility rate, which is due to other considerations that are outside the scope of this report, but it is a possible solution, and a financial solution, for those mothers and fathers who choose to have children.

I have been very proud to serve in a government that has a demonstrated commitment to work and family issues. I would like all senators to consult within their own families and communities on this issue so that when the final result comes, as I hope it does, it is a holistic reflection of the requirements of Australia's families.

talk.start.para: âLike the Chief Minister of the ACT, I have never felt so proud to be part of the Canberra community. In my adjournment speech this evening, I would like to focus on the caring sense of community shown by so many Canberra people. Reflections such as this have been long and loud in the Canberra community over the last few weeks, but now that parliament has resumed I want to take the opportunity to make these reflections in this place.

speech.para: Firefighters and hundreds of emergency services personnel and volunteers risked their lives and pushed themselves beyond their limits when they were confronted with the firestorm on 18 January this year. The heroism, effort and generosity displayed will forever be part of Canberra's heritage and history. So much for Canberra's alleged reputation as some sort of artificial city with no soul! No-one in Canberra has felt like that, and this is an opportunity to demonstrate to everybody that we not only have a soul but are an extraordinary city.

Like the dire circumstances in other places in Australia and around the world in which people do incredible things when confronted with adversity, here in Canberra we had our own confrontation. The efforts of many people prevented the losses of lives and homes from entering the thousands. We cannot thank them enough for their commitment. The service crews from utilities like ActewAGL and communications companies have worked tirelessly to restore gas, water and power to the thousands of affected homes, and they continue to do that workâit is not over yet, and will not be for some time.

Through all of this, the spirit of the Canberra people has shone through. There are countless stories of not only personal loss but courageous rescues, of whole neighbourhoods who banded together to save their homes and their neighbours' homes, who triumphed in their successes and grieved together in their losses. In the face of adversity, people risked their lives and their own homes for the sake of othersâfor their neighbour up the street; in many cases for people that might have lived over the back fence for years but they had never met before.

The Canberra community rallied together, helping their neighbours to clear debris, clean out gutters, block down-pipes and hose down walls and roofs, donating extraordinary amounts of bedding, food, housing, clothes and drink to local charities, initially through the evacuation centres and then through the traditional charities. Local hotels and motels provided free accommodation. Local businesses have provided goods and services without wanting any recognition.

How can we ever repay the hundreds of volunteersâmany of whom have themselves been severely affectedâwho staffed the centres and the phones around the clock? I know of many people who themselves lost their homes or had no knowledge of what was going on in their own streets in the affected areas who continued to work as volunteers through that period on that afternoon.

As the recovery from this tragedy begins, I have to say that we are extraordinarily proud of the leadership shown within the community and the leadership shown by the elected representatives of the ACT, with Jon Stanhope and the Labor government here in Canberra. They coordinated the set-up of the evacuation centres, which sheltered thousands of people on the nights immediately after the firestorm. Since then, they have established the ACT Recovery Centre, a fantastic achievement given the short time frame involved.

Having the recovery centre means that people will be able to receive support, advice and assistance with their immediate needs, including accommodation, financial advice and counsellingâthere is a child-care service being set up thereâall at one location. This one-stop shop environment minimises the logistics for people putting their lives back together. In my own visit to that centre, I saw that the Salvation Army was there, showing people where to go. So when you first arrived you knew where to goâsomeone was there to walk you up to the registration area and then down to the other support areas. That personal touch is incredibly important if youâas an individual or familyâ are facing a tragedy. People also have access to advice about the longer term support options that are available. I know that the contractors engaged to clear debris have also established an office at that recovery centre.

A bushfire recovery appeal has been set up and is receiving strong local and outside support, with many businesses and organisations donating quite extraordinary amounts of money. About $3Â½ million has been collected to date. From memory, the target was $10 million for this fund. I would like to mention some of the donors to that fund. Licensed clubs throughout Canberra have rallied to the emergency by not only donating large amounts of money to the bushfire recovery appeal through ClubsACT but providing food and facilities and supporting emergency services and the efforts of other organisations. In some cases, this was as straightforward as making sandwiches on the day. In the week following the firestormâ when Belconnen and other places were still on alert; we had no idea if the fires were going to come backâthose clubs made sandwiches to make sure that the volunteers, the firies and the emergency services workers had food to be able to keep going. Those little things really mattered and made a big difference.

A huge contribution was made by the service clubs, such as Apex and Lions. They acted immediately to provide people on the ground, supporting all kinds of fundraising. For example, in addition to their cash donations, the Lions Club provided staff for barbecue and drinks outlets at the Vikings rugby club's fundraising night. That was a particularly successful night, where a rugby union club got together with the Raiders and other league clubs to have a sevens competition here in Canberra. They had a great turnoutâ thousands upon thousands of Canberrans turned up, paid their $10, had a great night and watched some terrific football played by some of our greatest Australian football stars. Vanessa Amarossi and great local talent provided entertainment. As I said, many of the service clubs provided the support around that event. As well, many unions and all sorts of clubs have rallied around their members who have been devastated, who have lost their homes. Everyone who is part of the community through these clubs and organisations has found support there when they most needed it.

In particular, I would like to thank Chris Peters from the ACT and Region Chamber of Commerce and Industry and his staff for their efforts in coordinating many of the business donations. It was quite a logistical challenge. MiX 106.3 and FM104.7 made a great contribution to the appeal, raising $132,000 in a radiothon on one day. Individual efforts and donations have been outstanding. People are raising money for fire victims in very personal ways. I know of one couple who hosted a birthday party and said, `No presents, but donations to bushfire appeals are welcome.' The Canberra Capitals had a basketball game out at the stadium the other night, and they took money at the gate for car parkingâfive dollars a carâwhich went directly to the bushfire appeal. I mentioned that the Vikings rugby club hosted an event. Just about every clubâwhether it is a commercial licensed club, a community club or whateverâis doing some sort of grassroots fundraising to help in whatever way they can.

Canberra is truly indebted to ABC radio 666, 2CN, and its staff for their constant bushfire coverage, and for taking the initiative and having the flexibility as a local radio outlet to say, `Hang on, this is more important than what we're piping out through our network and we're going to follow it through.' There were a number of individuals who put themselves on the line to take those steps and made the effort to keep Canberrans apprised of safety issues.

There are many other things I would like to discuss. I have just about run out of time but one thing I would like to mention is, I guess, a warning about what seems to be an effort from some of the local Liberals to start playing politics on this issue. I agree with Jon Stanhope on the matter: this issue is above politics. We all have a long way to go in the recovery process. I would hate to see an effort by the opposition in the local assembly to try to make this their issue for the next local campaign. That is absurd and it certainly is not welcome or needed at the moment. I reiterate my comment that all the appropriate inquiries are in place. The response to this issue needs to be efficient, tight, meaningful and comprehensive, but most of all we need to support those people who did their best on the day. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âTonight I rise to discuss the issue of AIDS. In its third decade the AIDS crisis is still having a catastrophic impactâI think that is undeniable. It is a disease that strikes indiscriminately. The human toll is unbearable, there are countless children without parents and there are families without support. Fourteen thousand people become HIV positive every day and 42 million people worldwide are currently HIV positive or have the AIDS virus. AIDS claimed more than three million lives last year, with more than five million people acquiring the virus. However, it is believed that the worst is yet to come. The United Nations estimates that by 2010 an additional 45 million people will become infected, and in low- to middle-income countries 45 million. Such a staggering rate of growth is not inevitable; however, immediate action is required if such an outcome is to be averted.

speech.para: We all have a responsibility to address the humanitarian crisis that is gripping our world in this form. AIDS and HIV have affected various nations around the globe, including our own; however, today I will confine my discussion to the worst-hit places. Firstly, in the Asia-Pacific region almost one million people acquired the virus last year, bringing the total number affected to 7.2 millionâa 10 per cent increase from 2001. In China alone it is estimated that one million people live with HIV-AIDS, and a further 10 million are forecast by the end of this decadeâa number equal, say, to the entire population of Belgium. This epidemic is widespread and the virus does not discriminate. There are certain groups within the community who are at a greater risk. In the Chinese provinces of Yunnan and Guandong, HIV is prevalent among sex workers and, according to the most recent statistics, I think 11 per cent of them are affected. Much is attributed to an alarming absence of information about the virus and other sexually transmitted diseases and to the low use of condoms. Clearly, unsafe drug injecting methods dramatically enhance risk, and in some countriesâ namely Malaysia, Nepal, Thailand and the city of Manipur in Indiaâ50 per cent of users are HIV positive. This can be attributed to high rates of needle sharing and an alarming lack of available risk reduction and prevention services.

Sub-Saharan Africa is the most severely affected region. It is home to 29.4 million people who are living with HIV-AIDS. In 2002 alone there were approximately 3Â½ million new infections and 2.4 million deaths. Ten million young people aged between 15 and 24 and three million children under the age of 15 have HIV-AIDS. These are staggering statistics and are hard for us to begin to comprehend when we are talking in millions. Women are particularly affected. In fact twice as many women than men acquire HIV-AIDS. This is attributed now to a variety of factors. Women of this region face discrimination with regard to access to education, health care and employment. As nations' economies crumble, they become particularly vulnerable. As a result, women often seek relationships with those who can provide them with essential financial and social security. Older men are generally more likely to be in a position to provide this, but they are also more likely to have HIV or AIDS. In addition, social expectations make it extremely difficult for women to demand safe sex practices or to leave relationships involving a high risk of infection from men. This, coupled with a lack of sufficient knowledge about sexual health, makes women particularly vulnerable to the epidemic.

In some countries the levels of the prevalence of the virus are staggering: in Botswana, 38.8 per cent of the population have HIV-AIDS; in Swaziland, 33.4 per cent; and in Zimbabwe, 33.7 per cent. A very small percentage of these people who require treatment actually receive it, and millions are without vital medicines to treat opportunistic infections. There is a disturbing absence of effective preventive treatment and care programs, and this is indicative of the ability of the global community to adequately respond to the magnitude of the AIDS-HIV epidemic.

There is, however, some cause for optimism, and the success of sexual education, prevention and treatment campaigns potentially serve as a prototype for a broader, expanded strategy. For instance, in South Africa in 2001 the HIV prevalence rates among pregnant women under the age of 20 fell, based on the 1998 statistics. A similar decline, apparently, has also been noted among young inner city women in Addis Ababa, in Ethiopia. Infection levels among women aged from 15 to 24 attending antenatal clinics fell by almost 10 per cent, from 24.2 in 1995 to 15.1 in 2001. However, these figures are not typical and have not been repeated throughout the country.

Although such results are positive, they should not be the cause for complacency. Modest successes are undermined by disturbing levels of growth in some nations. For example, in eight West and Central African countries HIV prevalence now hovers above five per cent. Furthermore, although there has been a decrease in HIV prevalence among young pregnant women in South Africa, there has been a significant rise among older pregnant women aged between 25 to 29, to just over 30 per centâa staggering statistic. Clearly such a resurgence is cause for concern and underlines more than ever the importance of prevention campaigns.

This region faces enormous challenges in both sustaining and expanding successful prevention methods and in treating and supporting those millions living with HIV-AIDS and, of course, their families. This is a mammoth task. It is one that, clearly, cannot be undertaken without assistance. This is a global problem and therefore requires global attention. This epidemic also grips Latin America and the Caribbean. Approximately 1.9 million people from this region are living with HIV. Rising levels of HIV prevalence are believed to be attributed to unequal socioeconomic development and, as in many other regions of the world, socially marginalised sections of the community are particularly affected.

Finally, in the Middle East and North Africa a crisis is also taking hold with more than half a million people living with HIV-AIDS. Commonplace unsafe sex is something that needs to be addressed and in many countries the need for effective preventative and treatment methods is growing rapidly. In some nations ravaged by war and plagued with starvation, the epidemic renders traditional coping strategies useless. Weakened by AIDS, it becomes impossible for nations to cope with conflict and severe food shortages. This is particularly evident in southern Africa. This deadly combination so often evolves into a humanitarian crisis.

HIV and AIDS soon transform a food shortage into a food crisis as families and whole communities lose valuable labour and hence the ability to produce or afford food. This in turn leads to disrupted education, strained health systems, mass migration and increased sexual exploitation of women and children so desperate for money and food. Such factors all leadâit is a vicious cycleâ to an increase in HIV-AIDS. For many, there is no escape from this cycle. There is clearly a nexus between desperate food emergencies and the HIV epidemicsâwe have seen that; it is very clear. In South Africa, for instance, a nation in the grip of a terrible drought, almost 15 million people were living with AIDS at the end of 2001.

Households and communities affected by HIV-AIDS see a dramatic depletion in their labour supplies and hence their finances. Sick adults are unable to work on the land. Women and children are often required to care for the sickâdevoting less time to paid tasksâand therefore you see a slashing of the family's income. Farmers are, as a result, unable to afford pest control, weeding is neglected and the fields are left fallow. Many adjust their farming methods to cultivate less demanding crops, but profits are generally small with incomes severely restricted. In Kenya, the death of the head of the household is typically associated with transfer to smaller farms and hence a staggering 68 per cent reduction in the net value of farming outputs.

Women are severely disadvantaged generallyâas I saidâbut particularly when there is a husband with an illness. A survey conducted in the United Republic of Tanzania showed that women are devoting 60 per cent less time to paid workâthat is how much more time they are spending looking after the sick. Obviously the loss of a family member has unquantifiable repercussions for those left behind. Children who lose both parents lose the benefit of knowledge and skills traditionally passed on from one generation to the next. This means that many such children lack the knowledge regarding farming methods which are essential for survival. I do want to outline the good work that Oxfarm Internationalâamong other organisationsâis doing in proposing a comprehensive plan for action addressing HIV-AIDS, TB and malaria in unison. The response from wealthy nations has been lukewarm. Australia has yet to contribute to that plan and only with this international support can this plan have any chance of success. I seek leave to incorporate the remaining paragraphs of my speech.
Leave granted.

quote.para: The burden placed upon children is unimaginable, with many forced out of school to care for sick parentsâothers forced to look for employment to compensate for a lost wage. Some, along with women, even offer sex in exchange for moneyâso desperate is their situation.
In nations torn by conflict, war leads to physical/sexual abuse, displacement and destitution. An environment where AIDS/HIV thrives. The Rwanda experience provides an example of this.

Rape, aside from the severe psychological scars it inflicts, leads to an increase in HIV/AIDS prevalence among the civilian community as armed forces personnel are generally more likely to carry the virus.

Paradoxically, as the AIDS/HIV epidemic has been increasing, funding from wealthy nations has been decreasing. In 1998, for instance, funding given to Sub-Saharan Africa to assist 28 million people with the virus, was the equivalent of just $3 to $5 per infected person. This would barely purchase a cup of coffee, let alone provide treatment and medication.
There is an urgent need for action. As an international community it is essential that we come to terms with the magnitude of the AIDS epidemic.

There is a desperate need in many regions for preventative measures (including education regarding safe sex/safe drug injecting practices, and the provision of condoms), more effective treatment and care. Any such response must not simply address AIDS in isolation, but also tackle the factors such as food shortages and conflict (as I have identified) that so often compound the problem.
Long term strategies that boost livelihoods and save families from destruction must remain a priority.

As so many nations of the Western World experience heightened levels of nationalism and a belief in their independent sovereignty; obsessed with protecting borders, disregarding the United Nations... it is important that we stop and take pause... That we do not neglect fellow nations of the world. That we fulfil our International obligations. That we help those in need, where-ever they may reside.

I acknowledge the significant financial contribution the Commonwealth government has made to addressing this problem. I understand that in 2001 the government committed $1 million to the establishment of the Asia Pacific Leadership Forum on HIV/AIDS and $9 million in 2002 to an initiative designed to combat HIV related harm resulting from drug use in South East Asia and Southern China. Funding for both these initiatives came from the Global AIDS/HIV initiativeâa 6 year $200 million government program. However, having said, this there is still room to do more.

talk.start.para: âLast Friday, 31 January, the 6.24 a.m. train left Central Station bound for Port Kembla. As we all know, it never arrived. At 7.14 a.m. just four kilometres past Waterfall on the edge of the Sutherland Shire, in the tranquil bush of the Royal National Park, the train was derailed in a horrific accident. Tragically, seven people were killed and 41 people were injuredâsome of those remain in hospital. Whilst we can try to imagine the horror that these passengers faced, it is impossible to truly understand what they experienced as their lives and indeed they were literally turned upside down in an instant.

speech.para: It is also difficult to imagine the trauma that family and friends went through after they first heard the news and waited throughout the day for news of whether their loved ones were still alive. I take this opportunity tonight to extend my profound sympathy to the family and friends of those who died in this accident last Friday. I also extend my best wishes for a speedy recovery to those who remain injuredâas I said, some are quite seriously injured and are still in hospital.

In recent times in Australia we have had a series of tragedies involving loss of life which we have had to come to terms with. We have had the horrific events of Bali last year. We have had the devastating bushfires, particularly here in Canberra a couple of weeks ago. In this parliament today we remembered and gave our condolences to the victims of those fires. Similarly, this train tragedy has shocked and saddened us all, particularly those in Sydney and in the area where I live in the Sutherland Shire and the Illawarra.

I have spoken about this area in parliament on previous occasions. It is one of the more beautiful parts of Sydney, particularly the Royal National Park and the beaches. The shire, the south coast and Illawarra have enormous beauty. It is also an area that has faced tragedies before, particularly bushfires. We are familiar with the impact of bushfires as they occur nearly every year in that part of Sydney. We have had situations in the past where lives have been lost; so we understand and appreciate fully what the citizens of Canberra experienced just two weeks ago. Indeed, many personnel from our region were down here assisting in fighting those fires to save life and property.

What we also saw on earlier occasions, and what we saw again last Friday in Waterfall, was the magnificent dedication, professionalism and courage of our emergency services personnel and other authorities who responded so quickly to the disaster. The accident occurred in a part of the national park that is difficult to reach. There is no easy access, as I am sure people who have read the media reports have learned. Yet, within a matter of minutes once the alarm was raised and the reports started to filter in, police, firefighters, ambulance services and emergency rescue teams responded. No doubt, they probably saved lives through the assistance that they were able to provide as quickly.

Equally, stories of courage and assistance by passengers are being reported. Local newspapers such as the St George and Sutherland Shire Leader have reported on the acts of heroism of some of the peopleâof both passengers and the personnel who went to their assistanceâon that morning. I would just mention one, although there are so many. Gareth Redshaw, a student from Caringbah, was on the train. He managed to free himself from the wreckage. He raced along the tracks and raised the alarm by dialling the emergency number. He then returned to the carriages and assisted and comforted an injured woman. He remained with her for four hours. He is just one of many peopleâmany of whose names we do not knowâwho, despite their own predicament and their own injuries, helped others to safety.

The response from local services also was quick and professional. Police from the Sutherland and Miranda police centres were there within a few minutes. Officers and volunteers from bushfire services at Helensburgh and Engadine raced to the scene. Indeed I, along with all of the residents in that area of Engadine, heard constantly the wail of the fire brigade, ambulance, police and other rescue services vehicles as they raced up and down the Princes Highway. The emergency teams at local hospitals in Wollongong, Sutherland and St George along with those further into the city, such as Prince of Wales and others, were equally professional in providing treatment and comfort to the injured.

This tragedy occurred just five days after Australia Day. Australia Day is a day on which we celebrate the founding of European settlement in Sydney Cove, which subsequently led to the development of the modern Australian nation. Australia Day is a day on which the names of many Australians who are honoured with awards for service to their nation or to their community appear in newspapers. But the real people who deserve those awards are not the captains of industry, the politicians, the public servants, the High Court judges or even the sporting stars who seem to spend much of their time overseas. Rather, the people who deserve those awards are those who work in communities, either in their full-time employment or as volunteers, in emergency servicesâthose who are called upon in events such as that in Waterfall last week to help their fellow citizens. They are called upon to provide aid in disasters such as that which occurred last Friday or, indeed, in Canberra just two weeks ago.

On Australia Day this year it was a day of celebration in the Sutherland Shire, like everywhere else. I attended a ceremony at Cronulla Beach. The fireworks had been cancelled, quite appropriately, out of respect for the fact that much of Australiaâand certainly New South Walesâwas faced with a terrible bushfire threat at that time. But it was still a very festive occasion. It was the annual `Opera in the Park' festival. It was attended by many thousands of local residents and visitors to the shire and the beaches of Cronulla. At the start of the festivities, a tribute was paid to those who lost their lives in Bali. A large video screen was there and a video was shown. Particular mention was made of the courage shown by a group of young men from the Garie Board Riders Club. Garie is a small beach in the Royal National Park just a few kilometres from Waterfall. I would like to quote from the report in the Leader newspaper regarding the tribute paid that evening on Australia Day:

quote.para: A moving segment marking the tragedy in Bali and honouring six local boys who formed a human rescue chain brought many people close to tears at the Australia Day Opera on the Beach at Cronulla on Sunday night.

Sutherland Shire mayor, Cr Phil Blight, made a special presentation to the six young members of the Garie Board Riders Club who helped rescue dozens of people from the burning Sari Club immediately after the bombings.

David McKay, Brett Russell, David Roberts, Luke Gordon, Robert Meredith and Andrew Miller were given plaques in recognition of their acts of bravery before a minute's silence was held in honour of the Bali victims.

speech.para: It is people like those young men of the Garie Board Riders Club and all of those others who came to the aid of the victims and the injured last Friday in Waterfall who truly deserve our recognition. Tomorrow I will be moving a notice of motion to that effect in this parliament and I ask all senators to support it.

talk.start.para: â Firstly, I wish to pay tribute to space shuttle Columbia and her crew. The spirit of discovery they represent ensures that humankind continues to grow and advance. I am sure that we will continue their endeavour so that their loss is not in vain. I would also like to associate myself with the tribute just paid by Senator Forshaw to the people involved in the Waterfall train crash and the tribute paid earlier by Senator Troeth to the firefighters.

speech.para: Tonight I rise to contribute to the debate on Iraq that took place in the chamber earlier. In doing so, I wish to take a slightly different approach from that of much of the discussion that carried through this afternoon. I wish to draw a parallel between Iraq and Vietnam. This is a parallel that the Democrats have already been drawing with very little subtlety and that the Labor Party have been trying to draw with a bit more timidity.

On Sunday, 26 January I attended and was a speaker at the Springvale Lunar New Year Festival in Victoria. The opposition leader Mr Simon Crean also attended and was the main speaker. After speaking briefly in tribute to the firefighters he spoke at some length on his opposition to Australia's position on Iraq, describing it as a potentially Vietnam-like mistake. At the time I thought his remarks were quite inappropriate on a festival occasion like that, but I suppose the presence of three metropolitan television station cameras and a number of reporters from the metropolitan press put too much pressure on him. It is ironic that Mr Crean chose to speak about Vietnam amongst the Indochinese communities in Springvale on such a festive occasion.

Indeed Vietnam was an important watershed in Australia's collective psyche. Very few of us who lived in Australia in the sixties and seventies were not touched by the memory of the street protests, the way the community was encouraged to force the government to change its position on our international commitment on Vietnam and the way the community's resolve to take a moral stance on the world's stage was tested. However, the real impact Vietnam had on Australia was not of our troops going to and sometimes dying in Vietnam but of the subsequent coming of Vietnamese refugees to Australia after the fall of South Vietnam. That event was made possible by a courageous political decision by the Fraser Liberal governmentâ courageous because it was made not without political opposition, particularly from those people who stage-managed much of the protest, who regarded the Vietnamese refugee boat people as war criminals escaping from justice, which was easily proved to be a lie, and also particularly from the union movement, who saw it as leading to a likely reduction in Australian living standards. I remember a newspaper report of the then ACTU president Mr Bob Hawke threatening to take a delegation to Darwin to blockade the international airport when the first plane load of Vietnamese refugees were due to arrive in Australia. I cannot exactly recall whether he did go to Darwin, but I certainly vividly remember the newspaper report about his threatening to do so.

The coming of Vietnamese refugees to Australia gave an impetus to the development of productive diversity that is so much a character of Australia's multiculturalism. In a few years it advanced Australian multiculturalism way beyond what the original architects of multiculturalism ever hoped for. It tested and proved the Australian community's tolerance and acceptance of people of different backgrounds and cultures. It proved how these different cultures could work together to advance Australia's common interestsâour economy, our social developmentsâand gave us the society that today we accept as commonplace and take as a matter of course. So Vietnam's loss was Australia's gain. But that does not justify why Vietnam should lose these people or why these Vietnamese people should leave their home and loved ones and endure the danger of the high seas of piracy and uncertainty to come to Australia to build a new life.

Let me take the chamber back one step. Let us consider why our experience in Vietnam was considered such a failureâa failure of foreign policy and a failure of judgment. It was considered a failure because it involved the conscription of 20-year-oldsâat that time 20-year-olds could not vote as the voting age was 21. It was considered a failure because it was said that the South Vietnamese government was incompetent and corrupted. It was considered a failure because the allied strategies were said to be confused and the tactics blunderingâwe failed to win the hearts and minds of the Vietnamese people.

Senators would know that it is somewhat ironic talking about conscription for 20-year-olds when today 18-year-olds have the vote, and indeed it proves to be a passing concern. Sure, we can say that the South Vietnamese government at that time was probably incompetent and probably corrupt, but it was not the only government which was corrupt or incompetent. We in Australia have experienced some incompetent and corrupt governments, and we will probably continue to do so from time to time. The war was not conducted with a great deal of skill, but that is how war is sometimes conducted.

The important thing about South Vietnam, which a lot of people missed, was that it was a democracy. It was an imperfect democracyâas I said, it was incompetent and corrupt in some placesâbut nevertheless it was a working democracy. Elections were held and governments were changed peacefully as a result of those elections, although that only happened on one occasion because that is all the time they had. But they had a change and it was a democracy. As long as there is democracy people have a chance to change the government that they find incompetent or otherwise unacceptable. That is the nature of democracy. What Vietnam has had since 1975, after we withdrew and turned our backs on South Vietnam, is an undemocratic and despotic government. There have been no elections and there is no way of changing the government. There is no religious freedom. There is no liberty and no respect for human rights. That is what we have had in Vietnam for the last 25 or 26 years.

So our true failure in Vietnam was actually a failure of morality. It is not that we were immoral to be involved in Vietnam, but we lost morality when we gave way to irresoluteness and to those people in our own communities who put their own moral comfort above and ahead of our collective moral responsibility to the wider community to help our fellow human beings to improve their conditions. That was our failure in Vietnam. The lesson is that irresoluteness on our part leads to the betrayal of those people we should help. Today we Australians again face a challenge of this kind. We again face a challenge from some people in our community who would have us betray our fellow human beings who suffer at the hands of dictators and despots because it may cause them discomfort.

We have seen in the last few months the proliferation of Saddam Hussein protection associations right across Australia. People are sending out emailsâI have received hundreds of emails and lettersâand saying in newspapers: `No war. Think of the children of Iraq. No war.' Yes, let us think about the children of Iraq under Saddam Hussein's regime. He has been in power forâwhat is it?â35 years, 25 years? Think of the children of Iraq over all that time.

Surely all of us have a responsibility to uphold justice and right wrongs wherever we find them and to whatever extent we are able. Surely avoiding pain to ourselves cannot be the primary consideration in whether we do the right thing by those people who are unable to help themselves and need our help. That is the moral challenge we face on this issue of Iraq and whether we should be involved. It is not a question of whether we are dominated by the United States and following their example but a question of what to do about the people of Iraqâhow we can help them. We are not yet at war with Iraq. I, and I think all Australians, hopeâas the Prime Minister said this afternoonâthat we will not come to be at war, because none of us wish for war. We hope that, if any action is to be taken against Saddam Hussein, we do it with a new United Nations resolution and we do it together with the world community.

Let me make two points. Firstly, it takes two to make peace. It takes Saddam Hussein's compliance with United Nations instructions. It is not about the rest of the world wanting a war with Iraq or Saddam Hussein but about whether Saddam Hussein is prepared to comply with United Nations instructions and the wish of the rest of the world to avoid war. That is the first issue. Secondly, we would prefer to have a new UN resolution, as the Prime Minister said this afternoon, which sets out in unambiguous terms what Saddam Hussein must do and what we will do. However, I draw your attention to the fact that a newresolution is in fact not necessary. Under resolution 1441, Saddam Hussein is required to cooperate with UN weapons inspectors and to demonstrate that he has destroyed his stock of weapons of mass destruction. Failing that, the UN and the rest of the world are able to take action against him. That is an important point.

Given this situation, it is important that Mr Crean makes his own position clear. He is the Leader of the Opposition in the Australian parliament, so he is the alternative Prime Minister. He is not a heartbeat away from the prime ministership in our democratic system, but he is the alternative leader of choice in an election. He needs to come clean on exactly where he stands on this issue. Australians deserve to know, firstly, where Mr Crean and the Labor Party stand on the US alliance. Mr Crean can skirt around this issue but sooner or later he has to answer that question. The Australian people expect it. Secondly, he must come clean on his position on Saddam Hussein and the oppressed Iraqi people. Would he let this man,the Butcher of Baghdad, stay in power because it is too much trouble to get rid of him? Would he let Hussein stay and dominate and oppress the Iraqi people and their neighbours because they are too far away? That is hardly a moral position. It may be a comfortable position for the Greens and the Democrats to adopt, but for someone who is the alternative Prime Minister he has to prove he is not simply a pretender.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 15 May 2002:

question.para: (1) How many people are expected to benefit from the Government's election promise to allow voluntary contributions to superannuation beyond 70 to age 75 in the first year of its operation and for the 3 years beyond.

(2) How many people are expected to benefit from the Government's election promise to reduce the tax rate on excessive Eligible Termination Payments in the first year of its operation and for the 3 years beyond.

(5) (a) How many people are expected to benefit from the Government's election promise to reduce the rate of the surcharge contributions tax in the first year of its operation and for the 3 years beyond; and (b) how many of these people fall into the income ranges of: (i) $80,000-$89,999, (ii) $90,000-$99,999 (iii) $100,000-$109,999, (iv) $110,000-$149,999, (v) $150,000-$249,999, (vi) $250,000-$499,999, (vii) $500,000-$999,999, and (viii) $1 million plus.
