* This figure relates to expenditure for VHC services provided in 2001/2002. It does not include expenditure for services provided under arrangements with State Governments or expenditure for assessments.

(10) There has been a reduction of $800,000 in line with forward estimates as published in Portfolio Budget Statements. However, an additional $6m has been allocated to providers, reflecting the fact that some VHC services are, in effect, elements of respite care and community nursing and should be funded from these areas.

(11) (a) and (b) There have been no reductions in relation to any particular service type. Agencies undertake assessments based on assessed need and allocate hours for personal care, domestic assistance, home and garden maintenance and respite care based on that assessment. There are no fixed hourly allocations, however respite hours are capped at 196 hours per financial year by the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, and a limit of 15 hours per year has been set for home and garden maintenance through the VHC guidelines.
(12) No veteran has been denied access to services. Every eligible veteran is given an assessment.

(14) Nil. Agencies are instructed to review each veteran at intervals of 6 to 9 months or where the veteran's circumstances change, or at the veteran's request. A new approval must be recorded on the VHC system if any additional or different services are required.

(16) Data on this is not available. There are a number of veterans who are waiting for assessment and the timing of the assessment is dependent on the workload of the agency at the time of the veteran's request. There are a number of veterans who have been assessed and are awaiting commencement of services. There are also those veterans awaiting delivery of approved services that will be provided on an infrequent basis, such as home and garden maintenance or non-urgent home and garden maintenance and domestic assistance. These veterans are not considered to be on waiting lists. Nor are they inclusive of veterans waiting for reviews.
Where there is no assessed need for services veterans are encouraged to contact the assessment agency if their circumstances change and they require services.

(17) (a) If any, this would be a very small number and it is not common practice. However, there appears to be confusion amongst some agencies regarding the process of referring veterans to HACC funded programs, for example, veterans transferred to Community Aged Care Packages (CACP) that are often administered by a HACC agency. This does not constitute referral back to HACC program proper. Veterans currently on Linkages or Community Options Packages are in a similar position.
(b) Nil. However, veterans on these types of packages may be in receipt of other DVA assistance, eg RAP or community nursing.
(18) (a) 17,547 veterans have transferred from HACC.
(b) Nil.

(20) (a), (b) and (c) The Department of Health and Ageing have advised that:

Â· currently data on the number of veteran and war widow clients receiving (a) in-house or (c) emergency respite are not available. In future years, for clients referred from Commonwealth Carer Respite Centres, this information will be available through the National Respite for Carers Program Minimum Data Set and Reporting System, which is in the early implementation stage;

Â· in reference to (b) residential respite, the average number (per quarter) of residential respite residents who have been subsidised for the five quarters from 1 July 2001 to 30 September 2002 by the Department of Veterans' Affairs was 456; and

Â· for 2001-02, within the Home and Community Care (HACC) Program, some 554 âinstances of serviceâ were provided as respite care for Veterans' Affairs pensioners. The HACC data collection does not collect data on emergency respite.

Â· The Department of Veterans' Affairs has advised that the number of veterans and war widows who received in-home or emergency respite through VHC in each quarter of 2001-02, and 2002-03 financial year to date, are as follows:

*Note: This data is correct as of 25 November 2002. Since numbers of veterans receiving service is derived from the claims submitted by the service providers, the data is only as up to date as the claims.

(21) (a) and (b) The University of New South Wales is evaluating the VHC program for DVA. To date, a number of interim and work in progress reports have been provided to the Department, the most recent in August 2002. The key finding of this report are:
Â· Overall, 96% of the veterans rated VHC as either âvery importantâ (82%) or âquite importantâ (14%) in enabling them to live independently.
Â· The poorer the veteran's health, the more important VHC is in the veteran being able to live independently.
Â· There is a small (but statistically significant) lowering of the mortality rate for those receiving VHC.
Â· The analysis indicates that these increases in health-related expenditure occur prior to joining VHC, and start to trend downwards post VHC.
Â· However, these results are preliminary only. More data and more analysis are needed, as it is still too early in the program to draw any firm conclusions.
Â· A copy of the August 2002 report will be provided separately to the honourable senator.
(22) (a) and (b) No one has been denied an assessment. As agencies are paid on the basis of each assessment undertaken, it is unlikely that they would deny themselves revenue in this manner.

(23) (a) and (b) The community nursing program may provide personal care as part of technical and general nursing care services. However, veterans whose primary support is personal care are grouped under items reimbursed as activities of daily living. It should be noted that data relates to claims made for services provided in that quarter. Providers have six months to lodge a claim and, as such, data in 2002-03 Q1 is partially incomplete.

(25) The anticipated savings in the health program resulting from VHC will not flow from the VHC program itself, but from other DVA health programs. These savings are not being eroded by the perceived cuts to current VHC service levels. The redistribution of funding to regional budgets will allow services to be provided to a greater number of veterans in this program which is targeted at those with low level needs.
(26) (a) Average hours approved (per person/per quarter) by service type and quarter
(b) Number of veterans received VHC by service type and quarter

(27) (a) and (b) VHC has a standard fee of $100 per annum which is paid to agencies for assessment and coordination services in relation to each veteran. Some agencies received higher fees in relation or remoteness or other issues. The contracted fee is inclusive of administrative overheads.

entry.para: $25 per hour$15 per hour No copayment applies

answer.para: (b) The Department of Health and Ageing have advised that:
Â· the standard daily respite fee in Commonwealth approved aged care homes is up to $25.08 (as at September 2002);

Â· under the National Respite for Carers Program, funds are provided to organisations to assist them to purchase carer respite services (directly or indirectly) from HACC service providers or HACC associated providers. User charges are therefore determined by each provider; and

Â· a comparison of the fees paid by clients receiving HACC respite services and clients under the VHC program cannot be provided. Under the HACC Amending Agreement, State and Territory Governments have responsibility for the day-to-day administration of the program, including the collection of data relating to fees.
(29) Because of the delay in providers submitting claims for payment, accurate figures for expenditure for the first quarter of this financial year cannot be provided at this stage.

(30) Any reductions to funding available for service provision would not relate to payments to agencies for veterans' assessments, hence such reductions would not result in agency staffing reductions.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 21 October 2002:

question.para: With reference to the announcement of Westside Community Lawyers as the successful tender to provide community legal services:
(1) How much funding has Westside Community Lawyers received from the Federal Government from l July 2002 to the date of its successful tender application.
(2) Of the Community Legal Centres which service South Australia, which centres receive funding from the Federal Government, and how much is allocated to each centre.

(3) Will funding be allocated to advise consumers in smaller towns, including Whyalla and Crystal Brook, of the services provided by Westside Community Lawyers; if so, how much; if not, how will residents of rural communities learn of the service.
(4) When the outreach service visits smaller towns such as Whyalla and Crystal Brook, for how many hours will it be open.

(5) Does the service provided by Westside Community Lawyers also include a regional law hotline service; if so, is there additional funding for this service; if not, is there another group that offers a regional law hotline service in the area.

talk.start.para: âThe Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Westside Community Lawyers received a total of $123,208 through the Commonwealth Community Legal Services Program from 1 July 2002 to the date of its successful tender application on 9 October 2002. The funds were provided in two payments.

A payment of $69,948 was made for the provision of generalist and civil litigation services to the residents of the western suburbs of Adelaide. The payment is related to the organisation's normal service provision in Adelaide and is separate from its activities as the interim service provider for legal services in Port Pirie.

A second payment of $53,260 was made for services to be provided in Port Pirie for the period 1 July 2002 to 30 September 2002. This amount represents the standard quarterly payment allocated for service provision in Port Pirie.
Since the announcement of the tender outcome Westside Community Lawyers has received further quarterly payments of $69,948 for its Adelaide service and $53,260 for its Port Pirie service.
(2) Community legal services in South Australia which receive funding from the Federal Government are listed in the table below together with the funding they will receive in 2002/03.

(3) The Commonwealth did not make a specific provision in its funding allocation to the service to meet the cost of advertising the presence of the service in the region. However, I am advised that from the funding allocated by the Commonwealth Westside Community Lawyers has allocated $10,000 as part of its establishment budget to conduct an initial publicity campaign.

To date the manager has appeared on local radio and arranged for the service to be listed in the region's local business directory in order to promote awareness of the service. I am also advised that Westside Community Lawyers has set out the following additional strategies for advertising its presence in the region.

The service will place advertisements in local newspapers published in the Upper Spencer Gulf region, including newspapers which are published in towns other than Port Pirie. The manager of the service intends to begin advertising in early 2003.

The service will establish a reference group comprised of representatives from legal, business, local government and community service organisations in the area to support the promotion and development of the new service. The reference group's main tasks will be to identify priorities for the delivery of legal services and to raise public awareness of the presence of the community legal service in the region. The manager of the service has advised that the process of establishing the reference group is underway and that he expects it to be in place by the end of 2002.

The service is also working to develop a cooperative relationship with the local council. The council is an important instrument for providing information to the local community and the service will be enlisting its assistance to promote the service's presence.

(4) I am advised that Westside Community Lawyers will have an office in Whyalla which it plans to open for one day every week. The office will be staffed by a part time lawyer from Whyalla. Services to Crystal Brook and Red Hill will initially be provided for one half day per month. This may be reduced if use of the service demonstrates there is not this level of demand. The services will be provided through local council office facilities.

(5) The Westside Community Lawyers' service in Port Pirie is not part of the regional law hotline network. The Legal Services Commission of South Australia provides regional law hotline services to the Upper Spencer Gulf region.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Finance and Administration, upon notice, on 28 October 2002:

question.para: (1) Is it true that a computer programming or other administrative error caused the issuing of incorrect superannuation statements by the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme (PSS); if so, from what date were these statements wrong.
(2) How many people are affected by the error.
(3) Will this error result in all those affected having to do revised tax returns and having their tax re-assessed; if so, what is the range of additional tax that would be payable by these retirees.
(4) Is the Government considering waiving the additional tax payable; if not, who will pay any costs incurred by these retirees as a direct result of the error by the PSS

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) ComSuper implemented a new computer system for pensions in May 2002. In migrating pensioner data to the new system, ComSuper identified pre-existing errors in the Undeducted Purchase Price (UPP) and Rebatable Pension amounts held for some PSS pensioners. A decision was taken in June 2002 to review the UPP and rebatable pension amounts of all PSS pensioners, to correct any errors found and to advise affected pensioners of the changes.
The data was re-calculated from the date of exit for each PSS member. The revised UPP and Rebatable Pension amounts were provided back to 1994.

(2) Revision of UPP and Rebatable Pension amounts was necessary in 1,723 instances. This affected somewhat less than that number of PSS pensioners as some pensioners had errors in both the rebatable and UPP amounts quoted them.
1273 cases involved errors in the rebatable pension amount (549 overstated and
724 understated).
There was an additional 450 instances with errors in the UPP (184 overstated
and 266 understated).

(3) All affected pensioners were contacted in July and provided with revised information between July and September 2002. Though it is ultimately a matter for the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) to determine, the pensioners were advised of the potential need to contact the ATO for reappraisal of relevant tax returns. ComSuper has supplied the revised data to the ATO. ComSuper is unable to comment on how the ATO will consider these cases.
The range of additional tax involving errors in the rebatable pension amounts is:
Â· 927 cases (73%) are understood to have a maximum annual tax effect of less than $200.
Â· 306 cases (24%) are understood to have a maximum annual tax effect of between $200 and $400.
Â· 40 (3%) cases are understood to involve a maximum annual tax variation of greater than $400.
Â· The range of additional tax involving errors in the UPP amounts is:
Â· 366 cases (80%) are understood to have a maximum annual tax effect of less than $200.
Â· 42 cases (10%) are understood to have a maximum annual tax effect of between $200 and $400.
Â· 42 cases (10%) are understood to involve a maximum annual tax variation of greater than $400.
(4) This question should be referred to the Australian Taxation Office as it falls within their authority.
ComSuper will, on request, reimburse reasonable expenses that are incurred by PSS pensioners in submitting amended taxation returns.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 30 October 2002:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware that: (a) now that the Riverina and North Victoria are in the grip of one of the worst droughts in memory, the inflow to the Hume and Dartmouth dams is extremely low; (b) irrigation water allocations are unavailable to struggling farmers; (c) this desperate situation has led to a reported slaughter of more than 60 000 prime dairy cows from the Goulburn Valley, known as the food bowl of Australia; and (d) there will be a 90 per cent drop in rice sowing this year and very little fodder will be conserved.

(2) Given that there remains a huge amount of water in the Snowy Mountains storage system, at a time of such crisis why cannot the Government intervene to find a way of releasing some of this water to farmers at an affordable price.
(3) Given that the release of this water would have a flow-on effect throughout the region and could prevent many business and farm bankruptcies, what action will the minister be taking.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) I am aware that water volumes are low in many storages across the Murray-Darling Basin, and that many irrigators are facing significantly reduced water allocation in the Riverina and Northern Victoria.

(2) The Commonwealth does not have ownership of the water in the Snowy. The water is managed by Snowy Hydro under a licence from the NSW Government. Water is held in the Snowy Mountains storages scheme for a variety of purposes including irrigation and hydro electricity production. Reserves of water are also maintained to meet water demand in future years. Under the terms of the Snowy Water licence, governments cannot force Snowy Hydro to release water. Irrigators can however gain access on a commercial basis with Snowy Hydro to water in the Snowy that is additional to guaranteed annual minimum releases from the Snowy scheme. For example, irrigators have approached Snowy Hydro Ltd for additional releases, with Murrumbidgee irrigation negotiating a commercial arrangement for early releases of water from this year's allocation and advance releases from future years.

(3) In September I wrote to the members of the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council, which I chair, outlining the need to consider what opportunities there are for flexibility in providing water during these critical times. At its meeting on 1 November 2002 the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council directed the Murray-Darling Basin Commission to examine both short and long term options to improve supply flexibility under extreme drought conditions. This work is ongoing but Commission discussions to date have resulted in agreement to share projected shortfalls in water supply between South Australia, New South Wales and Victoria this season; a review of operating policies and strategies minimising impacts on water supplies; and agreement to a NSW request for an advance of up to 160 GL from the Snowy Scheme for Murray Irrigation Limited for delivery in the later part of the irrigation season.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 1 November 2002:

question.para: (1) What action has the Australian Air Force taken to address the significant shortfall of air traffic controllers that existed on 1 July 2001.
(2) How many air traffic controllers have been newly recruited to the Australian Air Force since 1 July 2001.

(3) How many air traffic controllers have separated from the Australian Air Force since 1 July 2001 (can the information on separations be broken down to show the length of service of those personnel that separated from the Air Force).

(4) Does the Australian Air Force conduct exit surveys as a means of determining why personnel with specialist skills are separating from the Air Force. If so, what do the findings of these surveys show; if not, why not.
(5) What is the current strength of air traffic controllers on air force bases.
(6) What is the required strength of air traffic controllers on air force bases.
(7) What action is the Australian Air Force taking to overcome the ongoing shortage of air traffic controllers.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) A Retention Allowance was introduced in July 2001 pending the outcome of the Nunn Review. The Nunn Review recommendations are currently before Government for consideration. The retention allowance, coupled with other pending initiatives, is considered to have prompted a significant reduction in Air Traffic Controller separations so far in this financial year in comparison with last financial year. A proposal to restructure the Retention Allowance to be skills based is under consideration by the Air Force. The final proposal will be presented to Government before the end of 2002.

entry.para: Number newly recruited as at 8 Nov 02 (including lateral recruitment and transfer between service)

answer.para: Note: additional 44 recruits (7 Australian Defence Force Academy recruits, 33 Direct Entry Officer and 4 Commissioning) are planned for FY02-03.
(3) The sum of separations since 1 July 2001 is 52.

The additional information sought in the honourable senator's question concerning separations cannot be broken down to show the length of service of those personnel that separated from the Air Force, as this information is not readily available. To collect and assemble this information solely for the purpose of answering this question would be a major task and I am not prepared to authorise the expenditure and effort that would be required.
(4) Yes, but the available sample is too small to draw any conclusions.

(7) An initiative to recruit up to 35 trained controllers into the Australian Public Service to supplement Air Force bases has just been approved. Recruiting will commence shortly with the first controllers expected to be in place in early 2003.
Air Force has recently completed the Military Air Traffic Control Capability Review that is currently being considered by senior Air Force management.

Air Force is reviewing the level of service required at various bases with a view to aligning the appropriate level of service to the traffic. It is anticipated that this will result in an optimal usage of personnel. This procedure accords with International Civil Aviation Organisation standards and is already in use at selected civilian aerodromes.

Air Force is also implementing a broad-based personnel strategy that should help to overcome the shortfall of Air Traffic Control officers. The strategy will address several main themes with multiple subordinate elements, including; removing unnecessary restrictions on recruitment, employment and development; enhancing career management; fostering greater involvement of Air Traffic Control officers in posting outcomes; and pursuing more flexible remuneration and conditions of employment.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 1 November 2002:

quote.para: (1) What action has the Australian Army taken to address the significant shortfall of personnel with specialist skills that existed as at 1 July 2001.

(2) How many medical assistants, infantry combat clerks, linguists, bearer systems operators, radar operators, special vehicle engineers, supply operators and terminal operators have been newly recruited to the Australian Army since 1 July 2001.

(3) How many medical assistants, infantry combat clerks, linguists, bearer systems operators, radar operators, special vehicle engineers, supply operators and terminal operators have separated from the Australian Army since 1 July 2001 (can the information on separations be broken down to show the length of service of those personnel that separated from the Army).

(4) Does the Australian Army conduct exit surveys as a means of determining why personnel with specialist skills are separating from the Army; if so, what do the findings of these surveys show; if not, why not.

(5) What is the current strength of medical assistants, infantry combat clerks, linguists, bearer systems operators, radar operators, special vehicle engineers, supply operators and terminal operators at army bases.

(6) What is the required strength of medical assistants, infantry combat clerks, linguists, bearer systems operators, radar operators, special vehicle engineers, supply operators and terminal operators at army bases.
(7) What action is the Australian Army taking to overcome the ongoing shortage of personnel with specialist skills.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's questions is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Seven Army trades were categorised as being `critical' on 1 July 2001 (Medical Assistant, Vehicle Mechanic, Missile Number, Operator Command Support Systems, Operator Supply, Operator Bearer Systems and Technician Telecommunications Systems)
Since that time, the Army has undertaken the following key activities:

answer.para: Â· developed a policy document that embeds personnel issues into the development timeline for new Army capabilities. This policy established agreed metrics for determining how to assess the health of Army trades;
Â· commissioned a comprehensive survey of critical trades to determine priority issues to address for each critical trade;
Â· undertook subject matter expert working groups to develop focussed action plans to address issues specific to each trade;
Â· developed a web site available on both the internet and intranet to assist soldiers and their families in making career related decisions; and
Â· in conjunction with the Defence Force Recruiting Organisation, developed a targeted recruiting strategy to focus potential applicants on the critical trades.

quote.para: As a result of these combined efforts Vehicle Mechanic, Missile Number and Operator Bearer Systems are no longer considered to be critical.
(2) Recruited to the Australian Regular Army (ARA) between 1 July 2001 and 31 October 2002:

Notes. Recruited figure includes initial (General Enlistment) and laterals, that is, re-lists and transfers from General Reserve (GRes), other Services and overseas. The trade transfer figure is the number of ARA soldiers transferring to these trades from other trades.
(3) Separated from the ARA between 1 July 2001 and 31 October 2002:
Notes. Accurate separation data is not available for Combat Clerk due to a lack of searchable identifiers for these soldiers at the time of discharge.

(4) The purpose of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) Exit Survey is to collect demographic and reasons for leaving data from permanent force members of the ADF (including members of the ARA) who are discharging. The most recent data available, which was collected during the period January-December 2001, contained 23 respondents from the following critical technical trades belonging to Royal Australian Corps of Signals (RASigs) and Royal Australian Electrical and Mechanical Engineers (RAEME), Operator Command Support Systems, Technician Telecommunications Systems and Technician Electronic Telecommunications), 27 respondents from the Operator Supply trade and 19 respondents from the Medical Assistant trade.

Table 1 shows the top five reasons for leaving given by all Army respondents to the 2001 ADF Exit Survey. Three main themes emerge from the data, firstly, a desire for stability in their home and family lives. Secondly, job dissatisfaction and a perception that they are not adequately rewarded for their work efforts. And, thirdly a perception that they need to leave the Army while they are still young enough to be competitive in the civilian job market.
Table 1. Top Five Reasons For Leaving Given By all ARA Respondents to the 2001 ADF Exit Survey (N=570).

entry.para: 1. Make a career change while still young enough.
2. Desire to stay in one place.
3. Desire for less separation from family.
4. Little reward for what would be considered overtime in the civilian community.

quote.para: Technical Trades RASigs and RAEME

Table 2 shows the top five reasons for leaving given by the following Technical trades: Operator Command Support Systems, Technician Telecommunications Systems and Technician Electronic Telecommunications. Respondents from these trades reported reasons for leaving that are substantially different from those of the Army as a whole. Themes to emerge reflect that discharging members of these trades perceive they have good career prospects in the civilian job market, feel they are not being challenged by their work and are not fully utilising their training and skills. Furthermore, respondents indicate that personnel shortages in units have influenced their decision to leave the Army.
Notes. Due to the small sample sizes in each of these employment categories they have been collapsed together to provide a more robust response.
Table 2. Top Five Reasons For Leaving Given by Respondents from Army Technical Trades (N=23).

entry.para: 1. Make a career change while still young enough.
2. Better career prospects in civilian life.
3. Underuse or non-use of training and skills.
5. Insufficient personnel in units to do the work.

quote.para: Operator Supply Trade

Table 3 shows the top five reasons for leaving given by respondents to the 2001 ADF Exit Survey from the Operator Supply trade. There are only minor differences in reported reasons for leaving between respondents from the Operator Supply trade and the Army as a whole. Apart from differences in order for some items, the only item ranked in the top five reasons for leaving for Operator Supply respondents but not ranked in the top five by the Army as a whole is `Lack of control over life'.
Table 3. Top Five Reasons For Leaving Given by Respondents from Army Operator Supply Trade (N=27)

entry.para: 1. Make a career change while still young enough.
2. Desire to stay in one place.
5. Desire for less separation from family.

quote.para: Medical Assistant Trade

Table 4 shows the top five reasons for leaving given by respondents to the 2001 ADF Exit Survey from the Medical Assistant Trade. Reasons for leaving reported by respondents from the Medical Assistant Trade differ substantially from that of respondents from the Army as a whole. Themes to emerge for respondents from the Medical Assistant Trade indicate that personnel shortages in this trade, a lack of recognition for their work efforts and poor handling of personnel matters are leading to lower morale among members of this trade and thus influencing their decision to leave the Army.
Table 4. Top Five Reasons For Leaving Given by Respondents from the Medical Assistant Trade (N=19).

entry.para: 1. Make a career change while still young enough.
2. Insufficient personnel in units to do the work.
3. Low morale in my work environment.
4. Lack of recognition or credit for work done.
5. Inadequate day-to-day unit management of personnel matters.

quote.para: Note: No data exists, or the sample size is too small for the other critical trades identified.
(5) Current Strength (ARA) as at 31 October 2002:
Note: Strength figure for Combat Clerk is the number of soldiers, irrespective of qualifications, posted into Combat Clerk positions
Note: The current required strength is the ARA authorised endstate for Jan 2005.

(7) The Director General Personnel - Army has a section permanently tasked to monitor the health of Army trades and develop and implement action plans to address specific trade related issues as they are identified. Trades are reviewed by this section on an ongoing basis.

Eight trades (from a total of 163) are currently categorised as critical (Operator Supply, Medical Assistant, Operator Command Support Systems, Parachute Rigger, Technician Electronic Telecommunications, Technician Radar and Technician Telecommunications Systems).
Key activities that have been completed this year or are currently underway include:

answer.para: Â· development of a trade specific recruitment/retention bonus;
Â· development of revised trade structures to allow development of sufficient numbers of Non Commissioned Officers;
Â· development of trade related pay cases for presentation to the Defence Force Re-numeration Tribunal; and
Â· ongoing targeted recruiting.

quote.para: The Director General Personnel - Army is now well placed to continue to proactively monitor and address shortfalls in Army soldier trades.

Key officer shortages are monitored in a similar fashion, with specialist areas such as Pilots, Nurses, Dentists and Doctors being categories of concern. Army and the Defence Force Recruiting Organisation are involved in implementing an initiative to target undergraduates in tertiary institutions. Initial feedback has been favorable.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 1 November 2002:

quote.para: With reference to the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee's Estimates hearings of June 2002, at which Defence indicated that the Incident Response Regiment (IRR) would number 309 personnel when fully staffed, and that 117 new recruits would be required to fully staff the IRR, with the remaining personnel to be `regathered' from those soldiers that were part of an earlier incident response initiative during the Sydney Olympics:
(1) Is 309 personnel still considered adequate for the IRR; if not, what is the revised number of personnel that is required to fully staff the IRR.

(2) Is the IRR now fully staffed; if not: (a) how many more personnel are required before the IRR is fully staffed; (b) when is it expected that the IRR personnel target will be achieved; and (c) what action is being taken to recruit more personnel.

(3) (a) How many separations from the IRR have there been since it was established; and (b) can a breakdown be provided to indicate whether the separations were by personnel who had been regathered, or whether they were by new recruits.
(4) How many new personnel have been recruited to the IRR since its establishment (that is, not counting the personnel that were regathered from elsewhere in the ADF).

(5) (a) How many of the new personnel were new recruits to the Australian Army; (b) how many were recruited from other parts of the Australian Defence Force (not counting the personnel that were being regathered); and (c) from where were the other personnel recruited.
(6) (a) Who is providing the training program; (b) has the training program commenced; (c) can a list of activities that are undertaken as part of the training program be provided.
(7) Is the IRR able to be deployed now; if not, when will the IRR be ready to be deployed.
(8) Can a breakdown be provided of exactly what the $18.5 million in the 2002-03 financial year will be spent on.
(9) (a) How much of the $18.5 million allocated for the 2002-03 financial year has been spent already; and (b) is additional funding likely to be required.

talk.start.para: âThe answers to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes.

(2) The current posted strength of the IRR is 205. (a) The IRR is being progressively manned with a further 104 positions yet to be filled. (b) The IRR will be fully manned in a mature state by January 2005. (c) Current recruiting efforts are on track to meet IRR manning targets.

(3) (a) A total of 19 discharges, which is less than the current Army average separation rate. (b) Discharges were from a mixture of existing and newly posted members and reflect natural attrition within the unit.

(4) The Australian Defence Force (ADF) does not recruit direct to a unit (except in cases involving local GRES units or positions earmarked for GRES). Soldiers complete initial training and, once their skills are assessed and manning priorities established, they are allotted to relevant corps. In turn they are then posted to units after completion of Initial Employment Training (corps specific training). A total of 69 new personnel have been posted to the IRR since its establishment.

(5) (a) Since the IRR was established there have been 50 soldiers posted in after completing their Initial Employment Training (that is, new to Army). (b) 17 personnel have transferred from other areas of the ADF and have been posted to fill specialist vacancies in the IRR (that is, changed from one Army corps or Service to fill a position within the IRR). (c) Since the IRR was established, one soldier has re-enlisted into the Army in order to join the IRR and one GRES member (a Biomedical Specialist) has been successfully recruited into the unit as a Direct Entry Officer.

(6) Individual training of IRR specialist personnel is provided by respective Corps schools (for example, the School of Military Engineering for Explosive Ordnance Disposal Technicians). In addition to this training, some highly specialist roles such as scientific analysis personnel will receive training from civilian institutions as an initial competency baseline. Enhancement of these skills will occur through employment and research within the Defence Science and Technology Organisation. These individual skills obtained by specialist personnel are employed within an operational context through troop, squadron and regimental training activities conducted within the unit and conducted in coordination with other emergency management and Defence agencies. Activities involving other agencies may include collective workshops with like response agencies such as police explosive ordnance disposal units or state fire hazardous materials units. These activities are aimed at exchanging information and ensuring coherency in procedures and responses at all levels. (a) In respect to the training programs, individual skills development and program is developed within Army. The collective training program is a collaborative process between the Attorney-General's Department and Defence. This collaborative training program is continually being refined to address developing threats. (b) Yes. (c) (i) The training of personnel to support counter terrorism operations conducted by the ADF Tactical Assault Groups. (ii) The training of personnel to support forces deployed on operations. This includes an ability to conduct reconnaissance of contaminated areas, detection of agents, monitoring for the release of agents, battle damage assessments, decontamination and the provision of advice to senior commanders on the Chemical Biological Radiological Nuclear and Explosive (CBRNE) threats. (iii) The training of personnel to support state and territory agencies in the event of a CBRNE incident.
(7) Yes.
(8) The breakdown of the $18.5m is as follows: Facilities - $0.5m; Capital Equipment - $2.0m; Operating Costs - $16.0m.
(9) (a) It is not possible to provide accurate detail at this time. (b) Requirements remain under review.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 November 2002:

question.para: (1) What is the status of the permissive occupancy arrangement between the State of Western Australia and the federal Department of Defence for the Lancelin Army Training Area.
(2) Is the permissive occupancy arrangement ongoing or subject to renewal; if it is subject to renewal, when is this arrangement due to expire.
(3) (a) What process is involved in the making of, or renewal of, the permissive occupancy arrangement; and (b) is public consultation part of the process.
(4) What role do the affected local governments (the Dandaragan and Gingin Shires) play in the process of making or renewing the permissive occupancy arrangement.

(5) In view of the significant and soundly-based public opposition to the recent proposal to extend the Lancelin Army Training Area, and the Federal Government's decision not to proceed with the extension: Will the Government consider terminating the permissive occupancy arrangement and relocating army training activities elsewhere.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The area is used with the ongoing agreement of the Western Australian (WA) Government.
(2) The current arrangement is subject to the continued agreement of the WA Government.
(3) (a) The occupancy by agreement is negotiated between the WA Government and Defence.
(b) The WA Government consults as it sees fit, but Defence is not aware of any requirement.
(4) This is a matter for the WA Government.
(5) Until an alternative training area is identified and available for use, there is no intention to terminate current arrangements.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 6 November 2002:

question.para: (1) What is the actual or projected Commonwealth outlay for each financial year since 1996-97, and for forward projections to 2005-06, for each of the following categories: (a) roads (including specific general purpose grants to the states with the intention that the grant will be spent on roads); (b) rail; and (c) urban public transport (can the information be provided in a table format).

(2) What is the actual or projected Commonwealth outlay for each financial year since 1996-97, and for forward projections to 2005-06, for: (a) aggregate expenditure on the National Highway System; and (b) payments to states for forward planning and/or land acquisition and/or environmental impact assessment for planned improvements to the National Highway System.

(3) What are the Commonwealth receipts from rail (including interest and loan repayments separately identified) for each financial year since 1996-97, and for forward projections to 2005-06, for each of the following: (a) the Australian National Railways Commission; (b) advances under the National Railway Network (Financial Assistance) Act 1979; (c) gauge standardisation agreements for Albury to Melbourne to each of New South Wales and Victoria; and (d) any other gauge standardisation agreements.
(4) How much money was spent on the East Coast very high speed train study in each of the following financial years: (a) 2000-01; and (b) 2001-2.
(5) (a) Why was a decision taken to effectively restrict phase 1 of the study to high-speed trains with a maximum speed of 250 kilometres per hour or more; and (b) when was this decision taken.
(6) How many tenders were received in response to invitations issued by the department to tender by 19 December 2001 for phase 2 between: (a) Sydney and Melbourne; and (b) Sydney and Brisbane.
(7) Is the Government prepared to give consideration to high speed trains with a maximum speed in the range 200 kilometres per hour to 250 kilometres per hour or more.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Local Government Financial Assistance Grants identified for Roads

answer.para: (1) Figures for the years 2002-03 are based on the 2002-03 budget figures. Figures for 2003-04 to 2005-06 are based on the current Forward Estimates.

(2) National Highways and Roads of National Importance are funded as one programme and, funding estimates for each of the two road categories are combined in the above table for the years 2002-03 to 2005-06. Funding outcomes for each of the two categories are precisely known only after final payments to the States and Territories have been made in the financial year.
(3) Roads to Recovery programme ceases in 2004-05.
(4) The State Financial Assistance Grants Identified for Roads were absorbed into general revenue assistance grants to the States and Territories from 2000-2001 as part of the GST arrangements.
(b) Commonwealth expenditure on rail:
(c) The Commonwealth does not usually fund urban public transport initiatives, but is currently providing $650,000 towards a feasibility study into a proposed light rail system for the Gold Coast.
2(a) See 1(a).

(b) The following table sets out for the years 1996-97 to 2005-06 the identifiable costs of forward planning and environmental impact assessments by State and Territory for the National Highway. In many cases however, particularly for smaller projects, planning would be incorporated into the construction cost. Land acquisition costs for most projects on the National Highway are not significant as the network is predominantly through rural areas. For the urban sections of the National Highway land acquisition costs can be significant. For the Western Sydney Orbital, the major urban project in the current programme, the Commonwealth's contribution to land acquisition costs is in the region of $300m.
The amounts for 2002-03 to 2005-06 are estimates only.
