5 (a) The Government announced that it intended to undertake a scoping study on the possibility of an east coast very high speed rail network. The decision to look at rail technologies capable of operating at speeds in excess of 250 kilometres an hour flowed from this fundamental stated purpose of the scoping study.
(b) Immediately; the decision flowed from the fundamental stated purpose of the scoping study.

6 (a) and (b) Twelve tender proposals were received in total. Proposals were expected to express their preference as to which segment they wished to be considered for (Sydney to Melbourne, or Sydney to Brisbane) or if they wished to be considered for both. Of the twelve proposals, five expressed a preference to research the Sydney to Melbourne segment; three expressed a preference to research the Sydney to Brisbane segment and the remaining four expressed their wish to be considered for either/both segments.
7 The Government concluded the east coast very high speed train scoping study in March 2002. No further investigation of high speed rail issues is being undertaken.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 7 November 2002:

question.para: With reference to the statement by the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, `Commonwealth committed to drought funding', issued on 6 November 2002:

(1) What method has the Minister used to calculate the `estimated $500 million' cost to the Commonwealth consequential to the administration of the Farm Management Deposits Scheme (please provide the relevant data and calculations used to support the Minister's estimate).
(2) In what year, or years, will the Commonwealth incur these estimated costs.
(3) How many farmers are accessing Farm Help welfare support as at 6 November 2002.
(4) Can information on farmers receiving Farm Help be provided, by local government area; if not, why not.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) and (2) I quoted cost to revenue estimates provided by Treasury. Cost to revenue estimates are the responsibility of the Treasurer and should be directed to him.

(3) Centrelink provides monthly statistics on program uptake. As at 31 October 2002, 1,025 farmers were in receipt of Farm Help income support. Since the program commenced on 1 December 1997 to 31 October 2002, a total of 7,284 farmers have received income support under Farm Help.
(4) Information on farmers receiving Farm Help cannot be provided by local government area. This information is not collected.

subdebateinfo.title: High Level Group on Property Rights
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 866)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 7 November 2002:

question.para: (1) When was the Commonwealth Task Force on Property Rights in Natural Resources formed.
(2) What is the purpose of the task force.
(3) What outcomes can be attributed to the task force's work.
(4) When and where has the task force met.
(5) Which task force meetings have ministers and parliamentary secretaries, or their representatives, attended.
(6) Which Commonwealth departments and agencies are represented on the task force.
(7) What resources has the department provided to the task force.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) A Taskforce on Property Rights in Natural Resources, known as the High Level Group on Property Rights (HLGPR) was formed in July 2002. It is chaired by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet (PM&C).
(2) The HLGPR was established to develop a proposal for a Commonwealth position on natural resource management property rights issues.
(3) The work of the HLGPR has helped to inform the Government's consideration of property rights issues.
(4) The HLGPR has met on seven occasions since July. Meetings are held at PM&C.
(5) Ministers or their representatives have not attended any of the meetings.

(6) Five Commonwealth Departments were members of the HLGPR; the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (AFFA), the Department of the Environment and Heritage, the Department of Transport and Regional Services and the Department of Treasury in addition to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet.
(7) AFFA seconded staff to a drafting team to support the HLGPR. AFFA officers were seconded to the drafting team for approximately six weeks.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation, upon notice, on 7 November 2002:

question.para: (1) Has the department participated in negotiations with Indonesia in respect to the Memorandum of Understanding Box area off north-west Australia in any of the following financial years: (a) 1999-2000; (b) 2000-01; (c) 2001-02; and (d) 2002-03; if so, can details be provided of these negotiations, including dates, locations and participants.
(2) What changes to management arrangements, including access for Indonesian fishers, have resulted from these negotiations.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Australia-Indonesia Memorandum of Understanding regarding the Operations of Indonesian Traditional Fishermen in Areas of the Australian Fishing Zone and Continental Shelf (MoU) and the area to which it relates (which subsequently became known as the MoU Box) have been discussed between Australia and Indonesia on numerous occasions since the inception of the MoU in 1974. The Department has participated in consultations on the MoU Box on two occasions recently - in Darwin on 9 August 2001 and in Jakarta on 8-9 April 2002.

Various Australian Commonwealth and State Government officials (including officials from the Department) and various Indonesian officials, primarily from the Ministry of Marine Affairs and Fisheries (MMAF), attended both meetings.

(2) The MoU Box is an extremely sensitive and important issue for both Australia and Indonesia. At the meeting in Darwin in August 2001, Australian officials were successful in engaging Indonesian officials on the issue and gaining agreement for formal talks on the future management of the MoU Box. The meeting in Jakarta in April 2002 resulted in the establishment of a joint MoU Box Management Committee, with the task of developing an MoU Box Management Strategy. Work on elements of the Strategy is being undertaken by officials out of session, with further formal talks currently scheduled to take place in the first half of 2003.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 7 November 2002:

question.para: (1) What role did the department have in the development of: (a) the National Dairy Sustainability Strategy; and (b) the Regional Action Plan.
(2) Which stakeholders were involved in the development of: (a) the National Dairy Sustainability Strategy; and (b) the Regional Action Plan.
(3) When were the following finalised: (a) the National Dairy Sustainability Strategy; and (b) the Regional Action Plan.
(4) Can copies of the National Dairy Sustainability Strategy Regional Action Plan be provided; if not, why not.
(5) Has the implementation of measures commenced under (a) the National Dairy Sustainability Strategy; and (b) the Regional Action Plan.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (AFFA) did not have a direct role in the development of the National Dairy Sustainability Strategy and the associated Regional Action Plans. An AFFA program, the National Land and Water Resources Audit (NLWRA), which is funded from the Natural Heritage Trust, initiated a project entitled âSustaining our Natural Resources - Dairying for Tomorrowâ with the Dairy Research and Development Corporation (DRDC). This work was undertaken as part of the Audit's Theme 5 (productivity and sustainability) and was also linked to the Audit's Theme 6 (capacity for change). The aim of the project was to review the environmental sustainability of dairy farm practices and develop plans for continual improvement in resource management. As a result of this work the National Dairy Sustainability Strategy âDairying for Tomorrowâ - a national plan for the dairying industry to work with government and community partners to sustain its natural resources and the eight Regional Action Plans (RAP) were jointly developed by the DRDC, the NLWRA and the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation (ADFF).

(2) The National Dairy Sustainability strategy is a partnership between the Commonwealth, the dairy industry, farmers and State and local governments. Key stakeholders involved in the development of the national Strategy were: DRDC, the ADFF and the NLWRA. Officers from the office of the Murray Darling Basin Commission, and AFFA attended meetings on the development of the Strategy, as observers. In developing the Regional Action Plans key stakeholders included; the DRDC, the ADFF and NLWRA, state agencies, such as the Environmental Protection Agencies, agriculture and natural resource management departments, catchment management authorities and regional development bodies.
(3) Both the strategy and regional plans were released publicly in March 2002.
(4) Copies of the strategy and regional plans are attached. They are also available from the DRDC website:
http://www.dairyingfortomorrow.com/welcome.htm

(5) The Strategy and the associated RAPs are now moving into the implementation phase. Areas of regional priority identified in the eight RAPs are now being developed into projects, the target outcomes of which should contribute directly to the âDairying for Tomorrowâ strategy. A listing of these projects will then be posted on the above website.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 8 November 2002:

question.para: The list of contracts signed in 2001-02 includes the following entry:
(1) What work did this contract cover.
(2) On what site or sites was asbestos present (indicate the nature of the site, for example, housing, warehouse, office building).
(3) What was the nature of the asbestos at these sites.
(4) When was the asbestos detected at these sites.
(5) What prompted the remediation of these sites.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The work represents the first phase of the removal of asbestos from Defence facilities in North Queensland, at a cost of $2.516 million over a three-year period.
(2) The sites from which asbestos is to be removed include:
(a) an underground communication pit;
(b) hangars and workshops;
(c) plant rooms;
(d) offices and workshops;
(e) offices;
(f) flammable liquid storage cabinets;
(g) fire doors;
(h) canteens;
(i) workshops; and
(j) hot water units.
(3) Laboratory results of samples of asbestos taken at the sites show the nature of the asbestos to be predominantly Chrysotile Asbestos.

(4) The asbestos was identified as a result of an audit conducted specifically to register the presence of asbestos on Defence properties. The asbestos audit for North Queensland was completed in February 2001 and was updated in August 2002.

(5) Until the 1970s, asbestos was commonly used as a building material in many Australian buildings and because of this common industry practice some Defence buildings contain asbestos. Defence takes the risk that the existence of this asbestos poses to the health of its people seriously. Defence is undertaking a 10-year rolling program that commenced in 2000 to remove asbestos from asbestos-affected buildings it now occupies. This work in North Queensland is part of that program.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 November 2002:

question.para: (1) Can a list be provided of all overseas property owned by the department, indicating for each property: (a) its location (country/city); (b) the nature of the property (for example, vacant land, office building house); (c) its current value; and (d) the use of the property (for example, accommodation).

(2) Can a list be provided of all overseas property leased by the department, indicating for each property; (a) its location (country/city); (b) the nature of the property (for example, vacant land, office building house); (c) its current value; and (d) the use of the property (for example, accommodation).

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Defence does not own overseas property.

(2) Defence occupies 18 offices and 52 residences under Memoranda of Understandings with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT): these properties are owned by the Commonwealth. As well, Defence leases 10 offices and 147 residences from DFAT, either directly (in the case of chanceries where DFAT is the head lessee) or indirectly, where DFAT is required to exercise the relevant delegation under the Lands Acquisition Act 1989. Additionally, 56 residences are leased for DCP personnel from the respective governments, some at peppercorn or no rent. The `current value of leased property is `commercial in confidence' and is not disclosed to the tenants by landlords and is, therefore, not available. This applies equally to the Commonwealth-owned property: DFAT - through its agent, United Process Solutions (formerly PricewaterhouseCoopers) - does not divulge the market values it obtains in order to calculate rents.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 November 2002:

question.para: With reference to page 294 of the Defence Annual Report 2001-02, which notes that the development of a Defence Workforce Plan has been `partially achieved' and that the report of the Strategic Workforce Planning Review was due to be presented to the Secretary and the Chief of the Defence Force (CDF) by the end of October 2002:

(1) Was the report of the planning review actually presented to the Secretary and the CDF by the end of October 2002, as foreshadowed in the annual report; if it has been presented since that time, on what date did this occur.
(2) If the report has not been presented to the Secretary and the CDF, why not, and when is it expected that this will occur.
(3) Will the report be publicly available once it is presented to the Secretary and the CDF; if not, why not.

(4) If the report itself will not be made public, will any material arising out of the review be made public; if so, (a) what information, if any, will be released; and (b) when is it expected that this will occur.

(5) (a) What is the relationship between the report of the planning review and the proposed Defence Workforce Plan; (b) what process is envisaged for determining the plan; and (c) how long is this process expected to take.
(6) (a) When is it expected that the Defence Workforce Plan will be finalised; and (b) will the plan be publicly released.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) A draft summary interim report was presented to the Secretary and the CDF on 24 September 2002.

(2) Following consideration of the Interim Report by the Chiefs of Staff Committee, comments are being incorporated in the Final Report. It is planned to deliver the final report to the Secretary and the CDF during December 2002.
(3) and (4) I will consider that matter in due course upon advice from the Secretary and the CDF.

(5) The report of the Strategic Workforce Planning Review will make recommendations for the workforce planning system to operate in Defence. While the focus of the Review has been on the strategic workforce issues over the next two decades, if the Review's recommendations are implemented they will start to feed into preparation of the Defence Workforce Plan for 2003/2004.
(6) (a) The current Defence Workforce Plan was finalised in April 2002. The next Plan is currently in draft as part of the annual budget cycle.
(b) The document is restricted and will not be released to the public.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 11 November, 2002:

question.para: (1) (a) What water-use efficiency projects has Land and Water Australia undertaken in each of the following financial years (i) 2000-01, and (ii) 2001-02; and (b) can details be provided of individual project funding, purpose and participation.
(2) (a) What water-use efficiency projects will Land and Water Australia undertake in the 2002-03 financial year; and (b) can details be provided of planned project funding, purpose and participation
(3) What evaluation has been undertaken of completed water-use efficiency projects.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) and (b) A range of water use efficiency related projects were undertaken by Land and Water Australia (LWA) in the financial years 2000-01 and 2001-02 under their National Program for Irrigation Research and Development (NPIRD). Some projects go beyond this period. Individual projects addressing water-use efficiency are listed below, along with details of project funding, purpose and participation.

entry.para: Economic benefits improved irrigation efficiency - estimate potential benefits and develop model for use by regional groups
Gaining acceptance of WUE framework - seek and promote national acceptance of water use efficiency framework, terms and definitions
Improving the WUE of Horticultural Crops - over 3 years
B Loveys - CSIRO(DNRE Vic, Agriculture NSW)
J. Mapson - ANCID - Australian National Committee on Irrigation and Drainage
Identify independent meter testing facilities, and develop irrigation meter selection installation, operation training modules and manual
L Humphreys - CSIRO (Murray Irrigation Ltd, Colleambally Irrigation Ltd, Murrumbidgee Irrigation Ltd )
Sustainable management of the Burdekin Delta Groundwater Systems - improve knowledge of impacts of management practices
K. Bristow - CSIRO(Bureau of Sugar Experimental Stations,CRC for Sustainable Sugar Production,South and North Burdekin Water Boards)
An evaluation of sub-surface irrigation - compare subsurface efficiency with surface application and define relevant management criteria
Irrigation Insights series - Partial Rootzone Drying - draft information document
Guidelines for efficient and sustainable trickle irrigation systems
P Thorburn - CSIRO(CRC for Sustainable Sugar Production)
Improved irrigation scheduling for crops underlain by shallow, fresh water tables
P Thorburn CSIRO(CRC for Sustainable Sugar Production)
Improving WUE by reducing groundwater recharge under irrigated pastures
H. Kingston - Agriculture NSW (DNRE Vic, Dairy Research and Development Corporation, Murray Irrigation Limited)
Determining Whole-of-System water use efficiencies for NSW river valleys
Development of Guidelines for quantification and monitoring of seepage from Earthen Channels
P. Jackson - ANCID(Wimmera Mallee Water, Murray-Darling Basin Commission)
Improving hydraulic efficiency of irrigation and drainage systems through benchmarking
An evaluation of short term weather forecasting and Risk Management to Improve Irrigation Scheduling
Investigation into the practicality of, and Potential for Controlling Evaporation Losses from on-farm Storage

answer.para: In addition to the water-use efficiency projects funded under NPIRD, LWA, on behalf of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry-Australia, are undertaking two projects as follows:

Â· To investigate the potential for government investment in reducing losses in irrigation water transmission systems and the potential for private sector investment in reducing these losses. ($50,000)

Â· Identify major institutional drivers and impediments, operating within and on water authorities that impact on the efficiency delivery and use of water, and to identify policies to support long term improvement in sustainable water use. ($75,000)
These two projects are being undertaken by Marsden Jacob Associates. They commenced in April 2002 and are scheduled for completion in November 2002.

(2) Following review of the program, NPIRD has been replaced by the National Program for Sustainable Irrigation (NPSI) which has a planned outcome of âsubstantial improvement in the environmental performance of irrigated agriculture and horticulture in Australia through the irrigation industry working, in a nationally coordinated way, towards sustainable use of the economic, environmental and social resources of which Australian irrigation dependsâ. Under the NPSI, LWA are expecting to have an open call for research projects in December 2002, leading to the commissioning of research on gaps towards achieving the planned outcome. Consequently there is no planned funding for water-use efficiency projects by LWA in 2002-03, at this stage.

(3) There has been no evaluation of individually completed water-use efficiency projects. However, phases 1 and 2 of NPIRD were evaluated and Phase 3 of NPIRD will be evaluated once research has been completed.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 11 November 2002:

question.para: (1) What funding has been provided to the Volunteer Farm Retirement Helper Program?
(2) What is the purpose of the Pilot Program?
(3) When did the program commence?
(4) Who is running the program?
(5) Who is participating in the program?
(6) Has any interim evaluation of the program been conducted; if so, can this evaluation report be provided; if the report cannot be provided, why not?
(7) Will there be a final evaluation at the conclusion of the pilot in December 2002; if so, will the evaluation be made publicly available; if not, why not?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Commonwealth contributed $37,500 to the Volunteer Farm Retirement Helper Program. A further $12,500 was provided to develop a supporting reference document on issues of importance in retirement and succession planning.

(2) The objective of the program was to conduct a pilot program designed to facilitate mentoring through meetings between farmers who have retired and farm families where the older generation are considering retirement.
(3) The commencement date for the project was 28 June 2001.
(4) The program is being managed by the Rural Industries Research & Development Corporation (RIRDC).

(5) The pilot was centred on northern New South Wales. This included the mid and far North Coast, New England and north-west of NSW. There were nine active volunteers and up to about 50 farmers participated directly with the volunteers. However, there were also a significant number of farmers who heard about the program and made informal contact with the volunteers.
(6) Although RIRDC has monitored the program, given the relatively short term for the project, there has been no formal mid-term evaluation of the program.
(7) A final report on the Volunteer Farm Retirement Helper Program is due to be completed shortly and is expected to be made publicly available.

subdebateinfo.title: Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry: Indigenous Strategy Steering Committee
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 887)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 11 November 2002:

question.para: (1) What recommendations has the inter-departmental Indigenous Strategy Steering Committee made in respect of the department.
(2) Can a copy of these recommendations be provided; if not, why not.
(3) Have these recommendations been implemented; if so, what has been the impact of the implementation; if not, why have the recommendations been rejected.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Commonwealth Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (AFFA) Indigenous Strategy Steering Committee is an internal committee that exists within the AFFA. It was established in July 2001 as a result of a review of Indigenous access to Departmental programs. As part of the 2001-02 Action Plan, AFFA researched and subsequently developed the AFFA Indigenous Strategy Statement (the Strategy) and Guidelines for Reaching Our Clients - Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander People (the Guide). The Strategy articulates AFFA's commitment to indigenous people and was developed as a signpost for staff outlining the vision and aims in terms of Indigenous clients and employees. The Guide was developed to present staff with an insight into Indigenous culture and provide guidance on best practice approaches for developing programs and services. These documents were launched in NAIDOC week 2002.
(2) Copies of the 2001-02 and 2002-03 Action Plans are available from the Senate Table Office.
(3) As the 2001-02 Action Plan and subsequent Strategy and Guidelines have only recently been completed, the impact cannot yet be assessed.

subdebateinfo.title: Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry: Agricultural Development Partnership Program
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 889)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 11 November 2002:

question.para: (1) What discussions has the department had with the states and territories since May 2001 on the development of guidelines for the Agricultural Development Partnership (ADP) program.
(2) How many ADP projects have commenced.
(3) How much of the Commonwealth's promised funding of $26.4 million has been expended.
(4) How much of the promised $26.4 million was carried over to 2002-03.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Officials from Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (AFFA) visited all States and the Northern Territory in November and December 2001 for discussions on program design and to encourage the development of project proposals. -Communication at officials level on Agricultural Development Partnership (ADP) program proposals has continued since that time and several preliminary project proposals have been received from South Australia, Western Australia and Queensland for informal comment, largely in the middle of this year. In addition to discussion over particular proposals, Commonwealth, State and Territory officials have worked to develop and agree Guidelines for the ADP initially in April 2002, and in more detail during July and August 2002.
(2) No ADP projects have commenced because State and Territory governments are yet to provide matching funding.

(3) & (4) Of the $26.4 million, $24.6 million was for Administered Items. Of the funding for Administered Items, $2.5 m was transferred to other priorities in the AFFA portfolio in 2001-02 and a further $700,000 remained unspent at 30 June 2002. Also, in 2002-03, $1.2 m was offset against scientific research into Southern Bluefin Tuna. Therefore, as at November 2002, with parameter adjustments, total administered funds remaining in the ADP program are $20.465 m. No funds from the financial year 2001-02 were carried over.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 11 November 2002:

question.para: (1) How much funding has been expended under the PorkBiz program.
(2) Can details be provided of all training programs over the life of PorkBiz, including cost, location, duration, number of participants and evaluation results.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (2) PorkBiz seminars were held at the start of the program across all six states, attended by over 350 producers. These were free for producers to attend.

There were 36 PorkBiz workshops, attended by 194 pork producing businesses (approx. 270 people), in the following locations: Gunnedah; Grenfell; Dubbo; Narrandera; Inverell; Bendigo; Wimmera; Shepparton; Toowoomba; Dalby; Murgon; Biloela; Mt Gambier; Eyre Peninsula; Coonalpyn; Barossa; Merredin; Kojunup; Narrogin; Perth; Launceston.

There were two different workshops running for 3 and 2 days respectively. The first workshop introduced producers to a benchmarking system so they better understood the current health of their business and the second workshop provided them with critical business planning skills and personal options to make more informed decisions in the future. Producers were also assisted in developing individually tailored business plans at the second workshop, and encouraged to take up the option to receive further hands on assistance through individual on-farm consultations.
There were 69 consultations for pork producing businesses (where often more than one person attended from each business), on farms nearby the locations of workshops.

The cost of the workshops and farm consultations was subsidised by the program by up to 70% such that producers paid only $400 for 5 days of training workshops and then $300 for the optional personalised on-farm consultation. The program aimed to encourage more than one participant per farm and hence a second person from the same business was able to attend workshops at no extra charge. Often a husband and wife or farm owner and manager combination would attend, meaning an estimated 270 people from the 194 businesses attended workshops.

Towards the end of the program, 16 pork producing businesses from two groups who had attended earlier workshops, revisited data and re-considered their position after another financial year, at one day follow-up workshops in Bendigo and Murray Bridge. These cost $150 per business.

Also towards the end of the program, an extended consultation was offered to those producers who had not yet attended workshops. These on-farm consultations combined what was offered through the original workshops and consultations. There were 35 extended consultations in NSW, Victoria, Queensland, South Australia and Tasmania. These cost $400 per business.

For evaluation purposes, PorkBiz was constantly reviewed by my Department against bi-monthly reports, and was also subject to two mid-term reviews of progress by the program consultants. Final reports for the periods July 1999 to December 2000 and April 2001 to March 2002 were also prepared.

Feedback from producers was very positive. Many producers have suggested it has improved their knowledge of the industry and their own business greatly and provided them with new tools to assess profitability. A specialist independent evaluator found that 88% of participants had learnt new skills and tools from the program to apply to their businesses. In addition, they had gained an understanding of the principles behind business planning.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation, upon notice, on 11 November 2002:

question.para: (1) What evaluation has been made of the effectiveness of the Eden Region Adjustment Program.
(2) What 2001-02 funding has been carried over in 2002-03.
(3) Why has this funding been carried over.
(4) Which funded projects expected to be completed in 2001-02 were not completed.
(5) For each delayed project, can the following information be provided:
(a) approved grant recipient;
(b) original and revised project completion dates; and
(c) reason for delay.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The broad objective of the Eden Region Adjustment Program is to supplement investment by businesses in the Eden region to create long-term employment and to advance the economic development of the Eden Region. The effectiveness of the program can be measured by the amount of new investment made and the number of long-term jobs created.

The Commonwealth Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (AFFA) seeks regular feedback from grant recipients to determine the level of investment and number of jobs created. To date (14 November 2002) investment totals $6,054,814 with 102 jobs created.
Not all projects have been completed yet.
(2) As at 14 November 2002, $435,000 of 2001-02 funding has been carried over in 2002-03.
(3) Due to project delays, encountered by the grantees.
(4) Boydtown Pty Ltd, ARV Motorhomes Pty Ltd and Goldbat Pty Ltd.

entry.para: Ongoing delays with local council for the building work.
Difficulty finding a contractor to carry out work.
Delays in gaining final Maritime Services Board of NSW certification of boat.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 12 November 2002:

question.para: (1) Can a copy of the current legislation relating to the debt management policy and procedures of the Child Support Agency be provided.
(2) When does the agency implement departmental policies regarding debt management.
(3) Does the agency accept a respondent's claim of income when the respondent owns and operates a business.
(4) Does the agency liaise with the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) on cases where income claims are in dispute.
(5) Does the agency have a responsibility to relay knowledge of a respondent's income to the ATO when it is clear the respondent has incorrectly stated his or her income.
(6) Does the agency have the capacity to request the ATO to audit a respondent's account when it believes there is an irregularity in the claim.
(7) How many claims of income irregularities were reported to the agency in the 2001-02 financial year.

(8) Of these claims: (a) how many respondents were found to be fraudulent in their income tax returns; and (b) were any of these claims investigated by the agency; if so, what are the procedures for investigating these claims.
(9) How many people are assigned to work in the complaints section of the agency.
(10) Where are these offices located.
(11) Can the agency take legal action against a respondent who fails to make a child support payment.
(12) How long can a respondent fail to make a payment to the agency before action is taken.
(13) What form of action is taken by the agency to retrieve monies.
(14) If a person is the owner or operator of a business, can the agency attach a lien against the business for monies owed.
(15) Has the agency ever taken legal action or seized an asset of a non-paying respondent; if so, in each case, how much was the debt for and what were the circumstances; if not, why not.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. The CSA is governed by the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989, in raising assessments and the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 (`the Registration and Collection Act'), which deals with collection matters. These Acts are publicly available on the Internet, eg at: http://scaleplus.law.gov.au/ or on the CSA's website at www.csa.gov.au.

CSA's policies, including policies in relation to collection are also published on www.csa.gov.au as `The Guide'. A chapter deals specifically with collection, and the Registrar's administrative and legal powers. The CSA's Debt Policy 2001 is also available by accessing the âlegalâ icon on the homepage and then through the âdebt policiesâ tab.

Child support debts, which have not been paid by the due date, may be collected using administrative powers set out in the Registration and Collection Act. These include recovery from the payer's tax refund (s.72), collection from Family Tax Benefit (s.72AB) or Centrelink entitlements (s.72AA) or by intercepting money of the payer held by other persons or companies (s.72A). This enables recovery from a bank account of the payer.
(2) CSA endeavours to make contact with a parent after the first default in payment. Different aspects of the policy are applied at any time following default in payment.

(3) The child support legislation specifies that taxable income is to be used by the CSA to assess the amount of child support payable. CSA accepts the taxable income determined by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO). If the ATO has not determined a taxable income, CSA will determine a default income using the best available information. This includes information provided by the client. If a parent's current income has reduced a parent can estimate their income. The CSA will verify their information when appropriate. Finally, the CSA can instigate a change of assessment process that examines the financial resources of both parents if it considers the parent's real income or earning capacity is not adequately reflected in an assessment.

(4) The CSA can adjust the income used for child support assessments where the taxable income does not reflect the income or earning capacity of the parent. This does not necessarily indicate the parent's taxable income is incorrect, or is in dispute. However, the CSA would advise the ATO of cases where it is apparent that a parent's income tax return is substantially inaccurate.

(5) The CSA does not have a legislative requirement to notify the ATO that a person has incorrectly stated his or her income. However, as stated in (4) above, the CSA would advise the ATO of cases where it is apparent that a parent's income tax return is substantially inaccurate.
(6) No. However, the CSA provides information to the ATO to enable it to make a decision.
(7) The CSA does not keep records on this information.
(8) (a) The CSA does not have this information.

(b) If a child support client believes that the other parent's income or earning capacity is not adequately reflected in the child support assessment they can apply for a change of assessment. A Senior Case Officer will take into account the financial circumstances of both parents and adjust the assessment where appropriate.

From 1 January 2002 to 30 June 2002, there were 10 074 applications made for a change of assessment due to this reason. Of these, 3779 resulted in an increased amount of child support payable. 2136 resulted in a decrease in the child support payable. 186 resulted in a change where the direction of the change is to date not recorded. The remaining 3973 resulted in no change, were incomplete, are still unfinalised or have been withdrawn. Many of those that resulted in a change would have been as a result of the changed circumstances of a parent.
(9) There are 27 staff employed to manage the CSA's complaints service.

(10) The CSA complaints telephone service is a national service for all CSA clients. Officers located in Canberra, Penrith, Wollongong, Box Hill, Moonee Ponds, Albury, Brisbane, Townsville, Adelaide and Perth respond to client queries from all areas of Australia.
(11) Yes, however the CSA would seek voluntary compliance initially, and then examine administrative collection approaches before considering legal action.
(12) The nature and timing of any recovery action is dependent on the circumstances of each individual case. The parents' current income and assets are important aspects to these decisions.
(13) Payment is sought initially via voluntary payment. If this fails, actions to secure child support for the benefit of the children may occur:
Â· Negotiated payment arrangements
Â· Employer Withholding (garnishee of salary/wage)
Â· Garnishee of other amounts eg. securing money from bank accounts, third parties, ongoing deductions from a contractor/subcontractor (for non-salary and wage earners).
Â· Deductions from Centrelink if a parent is on Centrelink benefits.
Â· Issue an order preventing a paying parent from leaving Australia while still owing a child support debt.
Â· Court action where an asset or income stream has been identified.

(14) Although the CSA cannot attach a lien against a business for monies owed, it can issue an order so that monies owed to the business are paid directly to the CSA. A court order would be required to attach a lien.

(15) The CSA regularly garnishees monies owed to a non-paying parent from employers, the ATO, Centrelink, banks and other third parties. For example, the table below provides information on some of CSA's garnishee actions for the 2001/2002 financial year.

Where a parent has an asset or income source that cannot be accessed through administrative action and a satisfactory arrangement for payment of arrears cannot be negotiated, legal action would be taken in the courts. CSA does not keep statistics on individual cases.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 12 November 2002:

quote.para: (1) Was Centrelink's performance in respect to the delivery of the Flood Assistance Package assessed as part of a post-implementation review program; if so: (a) what deficiencies were identified in Centrelink's performance; and (b) what recommendations were made to improve the delivery of future rural assistance packages.
(2) Have these recommendations been adopted; if so, has adoption of these recommendations improved Centrelink's capacity to deliver current rural assistance programs; if not, why not.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes. (a) While there were no significant deficiencies identified with Centrelink's performance, the review identified that improvements could be made through greater involvement of Centrelink in assisting client agencies with arrangements for similar assistance packages. (b) It was recommended that Centrelink and client departments work closer together on arrangements for assistance packages, to make greater use of Rural Call Centres services and to continue with the centralised processing of claims in a select number of Customer Service Centres.
(2) These recommendations have been adopted and have resulted in smoother delivery of more recent assistance packages.

subdebateinfo.title: Centrelink: Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry Programs
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 899)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 12 November 2002:

question.para: (1) (a) What are the details of the current Memorandum of Understanding between the department and Centrelink concerning the delivery of exceptional circumstances relief payments and other departmental programs; and (b) can a copy of the memorandum be provided; if not, why not.
(2) What payment did the department provide to Centrelink for the administrative cost of delivering departmental programs in the 2001-02 financial year.
(3) Is the department satisfied with Centrelink's achievement of 67 per cent of key performance indicators in respect to the delivery of departmental programs in the 2001-02 financial year.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) The Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) contains details of The Commonwealth Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (AFFA) and Centrelink's role and responsibilities in regard to AFFA programs delivered by Centrelink. In general the MoU sets out that AFFA is responsible for program policy development, while Centrelink is responsible for administration and delivery. Individual program Protocols operate under the MoU and provide specific details for each program, including a program description, services to be delivered, program management, performance information, funds availability, financial reporting and service delivery performance measures.
(1) (b) Yes. A copy of the MoU is attached.
(2) Payments during 2001-02 totalled approximately $6.2 million for Farm Help, ECRP, Flood Assistance Package and Sugar Industry Assistance Packages.
(3) Centrelink reports to AFFA on a monthly basis in relation to the 3 key performance indicators which are set out below:
(1) Determining that 80% of Farm Help income support payments are made to eligible customers within 42 days from the lodgement of the initial claim;
(2) Determining that 80% of Farm Help re-establishment grants are paid to eligible farmers within 13 weeks from the lodgement of the initial claim; and
(3) Determining that 80% of ECRP income support payments are paid within 42 days from the lodgement of the claim.

AFFA expects that all performance indicators should be met but is aware of the difficulty in dealing with the unique circumstances of each applicant. In 2002-03, performance against the three indicators has improved significantly against 2001-02 and AFFA is satisfied with the delivery of these services.

subdebateinfo.title: Agriculture: Tasmanian Wheat Freight Shipping Scheme

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 12 November 2002:

quote.para: (1) Has an evaluation of the AAA-Farm Help Program been completed; if so, when was it presented to the Minister.
(2) What stakeholders were consulted during the evaluation.
(3) Does the evaluation contain recommendations on changes to the program; if so, what changes does the evaluation report recommend.
(4) Can a copy of the evaluation report be provided; if not, why not.
(5) Has the Minister developed a response to the evaluation report.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes. A copy of the report was provided to the Minister on 29 August 2002 for information.

(2) The focus of the consultations were on farmers, Centrelink staff, rural financial counsellors and accountants, who are centrally involved with the administration aspects of the program. Other consulted stakeholders include councils, community workers, consultants, bank staff and industry representative groups.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on November 12, 2002:

quote.para: (1) Has a final impact assessment of the AAA-FarmBis program been completed; if so, when was it presented to the Minister?
(2) What stakeholders were consulted during the assessment?
(3) Does the assessment contain recommendations on changes to the program; if so, what changes does the assessment report recommend?
(4) Can a copy of the assessment report be provided; if not, why not?
(5) Has the Minister developed a response to the assessment?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answers to the honourable Senator's questions:

quote.para: (1) A final impact assessment of the FarmBis I program was completed in June 2002. The evaluation entitled `Economic Evaluation of FarmBis I Program and Approaches to Evaluate FarmBis II' undertaken by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) concluded that:

answer.para: Â· the long-term benefits of the program do not have to be large to exceed the costs of the program.
Â· over the three-year term, the program leveraged 1.3 times as much in participant costs as was expended by government.
Â· the report also recommended some further improvements in tracking to long term outcomes by evaluating productivity growth and amending data requirements.
This report was provided to the Minister in July 2002.

quote.para: (2) The assessment was designed to evaluate the effectiveness of the program by analysing data provided by primary producers through the Annual Follow-up Survey of FarmBis participants, Annual Industry Survey and individual participant application and course review forms.
Management agencies, such as State FarmBis agencies, the Bureau of Rural Sciences, Environment Australia and the National Centre for Vocational Education and Research (NCVER) were also consulted.
(3) Proposed changes focused on identifying approaches to improve the evaluation of FarmBis II, and specific recommendations related to this issue. The report found that there is:

Â· the potential to significantly improve any future analysis of the long-term benefits of FarmBis II by commissioning supporting research into differences in the productivity growth of FarmBis II participants compared with non-participants.

Â· the opportunity to collect a more comprehensive range of data for assessing the performance of the program. This would assist the accuracy of any future threshold analysis of FarmBis II but would need to be weighed up against additional data collection costs.
(4) Yes. The report is publicly available on the Commonwealth Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (AFFA) website at the following address www.affa.gov.au\farmbis.

(5) The report was provided to the Minister for information only. As the recommendations from the report related to ways to improve the evaluation of FarmBis II and were therefore operational in nature, the Minister noted its recommendations.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation, upon notice, on 12 November 2002:

question.para: (1) Was the review of Commonwealth Fisheries Policy, announced in June 2000, due to be completed in August 2001.
(2) Why has the completion of the review been delayed by more than 15 months.
(3) What stakeholders have been consulted and/or made submission to the review.
(4) When will the review be completed.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes, the initial review schedule envisaged completion of the process in August 2001.

(2) The completion of the review has been delayed for several reasons. The most important has been that during this period there have been three Ministers responsible for fisheries. Each has taken the necessary time to develop their own views on the issues being examined by the review. Additional issues have arisen during the review and many of the ideas developed during the review have already been implemented.

(3) It is difficult to estimate the total number of stakeholders consulted in this process as there were two rounds of port visits and a call for submissions from interested parties. In all 45 submissions were received and 25 separate port meetings were held. In addition to this, I have sought comments from industry during the normal course of industry visits. Stakeholders organisations represented the interests of:
Â· commercial fishing including industry associations;
Â· fishing industry manufacturers and suppliers;
Â· State, Territory and Commonwealth agencies;
Â· New Zealand Ministry of Fisheries;
Â· fisheries management advisory committees;
Â· recreational, game fishing & charter fishing organisations;
Â· indigenous fishing;
Â· fisheries consultants;
Â· academic and research institutions;
Â· the media; and
Â· non-government, conservation and environmental organisations.
(4) A public announcement of the findings of the review is anticipated in the near future.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 13 November 2002:

quote.para: (1) Has an evaluation of the New Industries Development Program been conducted; if so, when was the evaluation report presented to the Minister.
(2) Does the evaluation report contain recommendations on changes to the program; if so, what changes does the evaluation report recommend.
(3) Can a copy of the evaluation report be provided; if no, why not.
(4) Has the Minister developed a response to the evaluation.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) An independent evaluation of the pre-expanded New Industries Development Program (NIDP) Mark I has been conducted. The Executive Summary of the report was presented to the Minister in August 2002.

(2) The evaluation report contains 19 recommendations for consideration in the implementation of an expanded program. While the overall conclusion of the evaluation was that the business processes of the NIDP are sound and represent a firm basis for expanding the program, the evaluation report suggested minor refinements to some management processes. A complete list of the recommendations is available on The Commonwealth Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (AFFA) website.
(3) The report is publicly available on the AFFA website (www.affa.gov.au/agribiz) or may be obtained from AFFA.

(4) A formal response to the evaluation has not been developed. The report recommendations were provided for consideration to the independent Advisory Committee which oversights the NIDP. A number of the recommendations have since been adopted in the expanded NIDP.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation, upon notice, on 13 November 2002:

question.para: (1) Has a review of the Fisheries Resources Research Fund been undertaken.
(2) When did the review: (a) commence; and (b) conclude.
(3) Who undertook the review.
(4) What were the terms of reference for the review.
(5) Can a copy of the review report be provided; if not, why not.
(6) What changes to the management of the fund did the report recommend.
(7) Have all these recommendations been adopted; if not, which recommendations have been rejected, and why.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) (a) April 2001
(b) March 2002
(3) The Internal Audit section of the Commonwealth Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (AFFA).

(4) To assess the processes and controls in place within the operation and management of the Fisheries Resources Research Fund (FRRF); and, review processes and controls surrounding the selection of appropriate research proposals.

(5) The internal audit report on the FRRF was prepared as an internal working document for AFFA, and accordingly I consider it inappropriate for the document to be released. However, if there are specific questions relating to the operations of the FRRF, I would be pleased to provide the information.

(6), (7) The report made 18 recommendations relating to the administration and functions of the FRRF. Of these recommendations, 14 were implemented during the time of the review. These related to document keeping, the function of the FRRF Advisory Committee, operating relationships with the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE), the Bureau of Rural Sciences (BRS), and the management of the Fund generally. The remaining four recommendations are dependent on the outcomes of the Commonwealth Fisheries Policy Review.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 14 November 2002:

question.para: (1) When was the decision taken to sink HMAS Brisbane off the Sunshine Coast in Queensland as a recreational dive-wreck.
(2) Was there any consultation with the Queensland Government prior to the decision being taken; if consultation did occur (a) who was consulted; and (b) what was the nature of that consultation.
(3) Were any other parties consulted prior to the decision being taken; if other parties were consulted: (a) who was consulted; and (b) what was the nature of that consultation.
(4) Is there an established process for determining whether decommissioned navy vessels are to be sunk off the Australian coast as recreational dive-wrecks.
(5) (a) What was the total cost of decommissioning the HMAS Brisbane, and (b) what will it cost to sink the vessel as a recreational dive-wreck.

(6) Did any other jurisdictions express an interest in having the HMAS Brisbane; if so: (a) which jurisdictions expressed an interest; and (b) on what basis was the Sunshine Coast chosen as an appropriate location for the wreck.
(7) Did the Queensland Government raise any concerns about the decision to sink the HMAS Brisbane off the Sunshine Coast after the decision was taken; if so, what was the nature of those concerns.

(8) (a) Has any consultation with the Queensland Government occurred since the decision was taken to sink HMAS Brisbane off the Sunshine Coast; and (b) have any other parties been considered since the decision was taken.

talk.start.para: âThe answers to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Commonwealth's offer to sink ex-HMAS Brisbane as a recreational dive site off the Sunshine Coast was proposed on 26 September 2001 by the then Minister for Defence, the Hon Peter Reith MP, and accepted by the Premier of Queensland, the Hon Peter Beattie MLA, on 4 October 2001.
(2) Yes.
(a) The Queensland Government Departments of Premier and Cabinet, State Development, and Primary Industries.
(b) To advise the Commonwealth's position in seeking to transfer liability and responsibility of the vessel through a Deed of Gift and to ensure that the complexity of the project was understood.
(3) Yes.
(a) Brisbane City Council in July 2001, with regard to retaining the vessel as a museum/exhibit/ enterprise.
(b) To establish the suitability of the vessel for a museum exhibit.

(4) The established procedure for the disposal of decommissioned vessels for use as a dive site is that the Commonwealth would gift the vessel to the relevant state government, which would then manage the entire process. This is to ensure issues such as resources, planning and environmental management is fully addressed.

(5) (a) The costs associated with decommissioning ex HMAS Brisbane are estimated to be $762,000 and include security, trades assistants, craneage and miscellaneous hire of equipment. However, it does not include the cost of work that was completed gratis, or removal of items for re-utilisation and display at the Australian War Memorial.
(b) From past experience the cost to prepare, tow and sink a vessel of this size is estimated to be $3 million.
(6) Yes.

(a) The New South Wales and Western Australian State Governments submitted requests for the vessel to be utilised for tourism purposes as a dive-wreck artificial reef. Community groups, councils and individuals also expressed interest.

(b) The site was chosen in response to the Premier of Queensland's letter of 8 August 2000 to the then Minister for Defence, the Hon John Moore MP, in requesting assistance to secure the vessel for the establishment of an artificial reef off the Sunshine Coast.

(7) Yes. Concerns were raised from the Premier in May 2002 regarding the lack of consultation in the selection of the site off the Sunshine Coast, nomination of other interested parties in Queensland, and a view that the Commonwealth should manage the total project, given the liability and risks involved.

The Minister for Defence responded to these concerns in May 2002. Specifically, the Minister for Defence advised Premier Beattie that these concerns were unexpected as the Commonwealth had been prepared to gift the vessel to the people of Queensland, provide funding for the project and site the vessel off the Sunshine Coast in accordance with Premier Beattie's specific requirements.
(8) (a) Yes. Extensive negotiation has occurred in an attempt to finalise the Deed of Gift arrangements.
(b) No.

For the Department of Defence to provide a complete response would require considerable time and resources and, in the interest of efficient utilisation of departmental resources, the Minister for Defence advised in response to Senate Question on Notice 692 that he is not prepared to authorise the expenditure of resources and effort to provide the information requested.

(5) (a) The following is a complete list of current deployments that have coverage under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.

answer.para: (b) See part (1) above.
(6) (a) and (b) See part (1) above.
(7) Service in the events for which the following medals are awarded qualifies for the Peace Operations Certificate of Appreciation.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation, upon notice, on 14 November 2002:

question.para: With reference to the recently-launched Australian Forestry Standard (AFS):
(1) Who decides whether a company or product receives an AFS certification label?
(2) By what process is an AFS certification application assessed?
(3) Is it only timber products that can receive AFS certification or can companies and government agencies receive AFS certification?
(4) Will companies involved in, or products produced from, logging of old-growth forests or clearing of rainforests anywhere in Australia be eligible for AFS certification?

(5) Will any logging operations, Regional Forest Agreements or forest management plans anywhere in Australia be changed to any significant degree as a result of the introduction or awarding of AFS certification?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Australian Forestry Standard (AFS) is a basis for certification of forest management within a defined forest area, it is not for certification of a company or product. At this stage there is no AFS label.

The Joint Accreditation System Australia and New Zealand (JAS ANZ), Australia and New Zealand's national body for accreditation of certification bodies, is developing a programme for accrediting third party independent bodies that will assess whether forest management meets the requirements for AFS certification.
(2) The certification framework is described in detail at Section 5 of the AFS. A pre-publication copy is available at the AFS website: www.forestrystandard.org.au.
(3) Timber products, companies or Government agencies do not receive AFS certification, instead management of a defined forest area is certified.
A certificate could be held by a company or Government agency but equally by an individual landholder or a group of forest managers acting in a cooperative manner.

(4) AFS certification is a voluntary undertaking and consistent with other international certification schemes such as the Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) scheme. Any forest managed for wood production may be assessed against the requirements contained in the Standard. However, the AFS has a clear definition of what significant biological diversity values need to be maintained. These include protecting forest types (such as rainforest) and old-growth forest, which are threatened or under represented in the forest reserve system.

(5) Certification of Australian forest managers will require a thorough review of their management practices to ensure that they comply with the requirements in the AFS. In some circumstances, change may be required to achieve certification. AFS certification will not necessitate any changes to RFAs.

subdebateinfo.title: Health: Dungog and District Neighbour Care Inc.
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 926)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 14 November 2002:

question.para: (1) What funds has the Commonwealth given to Dungog and District Neighbour Care Inc.
(2) (a) How much funding was provided; and (b) under what program.
(3) Are these funds still available to Dungog and District Neighbour Care Inc.; if not, why not.
(4) If these funds are no longer available to Dungog and District Neighbour Care Inc., what has happened to these funds.

(5) Were the funds for Dungog and District Neighbour Care Inc. transferred to another service provider; if so: (a) why were they transferred; (b) to which service provider were they transferred; and (c) for what period of time.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Funds given by the Commonwealth to Dungog and District Neighbour Care Incorporated:
(2) (a) See above; and (b) The Community Aged Care Packages (CACP) program.

(3) CACP subsidy is a payment by the Commonwealth to approved providers for providing community care to approved care recipients. It is paid monthly and the amount paid for a month is the sum of the amounts due for each day of the month for each subsidised care recipient. Providers are required to submit a claim for each month containing details of each care recipient for whom they are claiming subsidy in that month. Providers receive an advance payment in the first few days of each month. This is reconciled with the claim for that month and an adjustment is made, either by making a further payment or by reducing the next advance.

Dungog and District Neighbourcare Incorporated's latest claim for payment was made only up to 17 November 2002 and is being processed accordingly. It is understood the provider has not provided services to any care recipients since that date
(4) See response to (3)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 15 November 2002:

quote.para: (1) Are there plans to expand the Lancelin Defence Training Area.
(2) Are there plans to allow United States military forces to use the Lancelin Defence Training Area.
(3) Are there any risks to public health with such an expansion.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) No. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence, the Hon Fran Bailey MP, announced on 13 August 2002 that Defence would not proceed with a previous proposal to extend the existing Lancelin Defence Training Area and that alternative sites suitable as Army training areas would be investigated.

(2) The United States military forces have used Lancelin in the past, and future requests will be considered on a case by case basis. Defence is strongly committed to responsible use of the Area, including ongoing maintenance and protection of the environment, and requires that same commitment from any ally requesting access to the Area.
(3) Not applicable.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 14 November 2002:

question.para: (1) As the majority of burns victims from the recent tragedy in Bali were treated at the Burns Unit at Royal Perth Hospital, will the Commonwealth be providing any additional funding to the unit; if so, how much; if not, why not.
(2) Will any other additional funding be provided to Western Australia in light of the extraordinary demand on health services following the tragedy in Bali.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Government acknowledges the excellent care that Royal Perth Hospital has provided to patients injured in the Bali disaster. Western Australia has responsibility for the patients that are residents of that State and other eligible persons being treated as public patients. The Australian Health Care Agreements between the Commonwealth and States and Territories provide for mechanisms to adjust for costs incurred where admitted patient services are delivered to patients who are residents of other States and Territories.
It remains to be seen whether any additional assistance would be appropriate once those arrangements have been implemented in regard to patients injured by the Bali disaster.

(2) If Western Australia makes a case for additional funding that will be considered on its merits. However, the Commonwealth has been providing a range of measures that complement State and Territory efforts. These include:
Â· providing medical evacuation of Australians and some foreign nationals from Bali to Australia;
Â· paying for the full out-of-pocket (ie., those not covered by Medicare, insurance or other disaster related assistance) health care expenses of Medicare-eligible victims of the Bali bombing;
Â· streamlining access for victims of the disaster and their families to Centrelink payments and services for which they may be eligible;
Â· giving financial assistance to immediate family who may have to travel interstate to visit their relatives in hospital;
Â· giving financial assistance for the injured and their immediate family to return home following discharge from hospital (this would normally be undertaken by States and Territories); and
Â· considering other assistance measures, on a case by case basis, where costs are incurred which fall outside the above categories and which cause particular hardship.

I take this opportunity to extend the Government's deep appreciation of the professional and dedicated work done by staff at the Royal Perth Hospital and hospitals around Australia to respond to the Bali crisis, and for the remarkable level of cooperation achieved between the Commonwealth, States and Territory governments during this tragic event.

quote.para: (1) Negotiations with the Commonwealth Department of the Environment and Heritage (EA) on a memorandum of understanding or consideration of environment issues in import risk analyses carried out by the Commonwealth Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (AFFA) commenced in July 2001.

(2) The Memorandum of Understanding between Biosecurity Australia and Environment Australia was signed by Michael Taylor (Secretary, AFFA) and Roger Beale (Secretary, EA) on 11 October 2002. Copies are available from the Senate Table Office.

(9) Has anyone else sought access to data held on the database.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) Consistent with past practice in similar exercises, the contact details of those who made submissions or were otherwise involved in the Independent Assessment of the Sugar Industry were recorded on a simple spreadsheet and email distribution list. This included the names, addresses, telephone numbers and email addresses of individuals and organisations who made written submissions or otherwise expressed an interest in the Independent Assessment of the Sugar Industry.

answer.para: Â· 39 are identifiable as companies (including some cane-growing enterprises); and

subdebateinfo.title: Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry: Performance Payments
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 945)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 18 November 2002:

quote.para: (1) (a) What was the largest individual performance bonus received by a staff member of the department in the 2001-02 financial year; and (b) what was the employee staff classification of the staff member.

(2) What was the smallest individual performance bonus received by a staff member of the department in the 2001-02 financial year; and (b) what was the employee staff classification of the staff member.

(3) In relation to performance payments to Senior Executive Service (SES) staff: (a) what performance criteria were used to assess the quantum of performance pay; (b) who assessed the performance against the criteria; and (c) who was the decision-maker.
(4) Was the Minister and/or his office consulted or involved in the decision-making process in relation to the payment of SES staff performance bonuses.

(5) In relation to the payment of a performance bonus to the Secretary of the Department, what was the quantum of the bonus, if any, in each of the following financial years: (a) 1999-2000; (b) 2000-01; and (c) 2001-02.
(6) If a performance bonus was paid to the Secretary of the Department in the 2001-02 financial year: why is the quantum of the bonus not divulged in the department's annual report for 2001-02.

(7) In relation to the payment of a performance bonus to the Secretary of the Department in the 2001-02 financial year, if any: (a) what performance criteria were used; (b) who assessed the Secretary's performance against the criteria; (c) who was the decision-maker; and (d) what role did the Minister and/or his office have in relation to the payment.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) (a) The largest individual performance bonus received by a staff member of the Commonwealth Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (AFFA) in the 2001-02 financial year was 13.56%; and (b) the employee staff classification was Senior Executive Service Band 3.

(2) The smallest individual performance bonus received by a staff member of AFFA in the 2001-02 financial year was 1.03%; and (b) the employee staff classification of the staff member was DPIE Band 3 AFFA Level 8(A).

(3) In relation to performance payments to Senior Executive Service (SES) staff: (a) 7 standard performance criteria are included in SES Performance Agreements - business/projects, people, values, finance, corporate support, clients, and innovation. (b) In determining the level of bonuses, a number of sources of information and advice are considered, including a Remuneration Committee (consisting of the Deputy Secretaries and the Secretary for AFFA), performance appraisal reports and further information from Executive Directors and Business Managers if necessary. (c) The Secretary for AFFA

(5) (6) and (7) The Prime Minister determines the payment of any performance bonuses to Secretaries. Questions about performance pay arrangements for Secretaries would therefore more appropriately be directed to him.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 18 November 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is it the case that no Indigenous Australians were employed at Senior Executive Service (SES) Band 1, 2 or 3 within the department in the 2001-02 financial year.
(2) Is it the case that no persons from non-English speaking background were employed at SES Band 1, 2 or 3 within the department in the 2001-02 financial year.
(3) Is it the case that just one person with a disability was employed at SES Band 1, 2 or 3 within the department in the 2001-02 financial year.
(4) Is the Minister satisfied with the workplace diversity at senior levels of his department.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) Of those individuals employed at Senior Executive Service (SES) Band 1, 2, or 3 within the Commonwealth Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry (AFFA) in the 2001-02 financial year, none identified themselves as Indigenous Australians.

(2) Of those individuals employed at Senior Executive Service (SES) Band 1, 2, or 3 within AFFA in the 2001-02 financial year, none identified themselves as coming from a non-English speaking background.
(3) Of those individuals employed at Senior Executive Service (SES) Band 1, 2, or 3 within AFFA in the 2001-02 financial year, one identified themself as being a person with a disability.

(4) Yes. AFFA supports and encourages applications from individuals as identified above. Notwithstanding, it is important to ensure that the principle of merit is adhered to in all selection exercises. The provision of workplace diversity personal information is not mandatory, however, successful applicants are encouraged to volunteer information of this nature. As such the department's records are not necessarily an accurate reflection of the position.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 18 November 2002:

Senator Ian Macdonald

answer.para: Â· decide on the procurement process based on which option represents the most efficient and effective use of public monies. Purchases over $100,000 should be made via open public tender.
