talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 18 November 2002:

quote.para: Has the Government considered posting Medicare rebate cheques for accounts not yet paid directly to the practitioner, rather than to the patient; if so, what was the outcome of such consideration.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: No. Subsection 20(1) of the Health Insurance Act 1973 provides that Medicare benefits are payable only to the person who incurs the medical expenses (`the patient'). Therefore, Medicare rebate cheques are not able to be paid directly to the practitioner.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 20 November 2002:

quote.para: (1) With reference to the proposed Bickham coal mine near Murrurundi, New South Wales: what notification has the Federal Government had about the project.
(2) Are proposed water extractions from the Pages River during studies, or when the mine is established, within national guidelines and water policy.
(3) What environmental assessment has been carried out on mine feasibility studies and/or the impact on the Pages River of a working mine.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) This proposal has not been referred under the Environment Protection & Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 nor am I aware of any other notification having been made to the Commonwealth.

(2) The Department of the Environment and Heritage has been advised by NSW authorities that no water will be taken from the Pages River. The advice from NSW is that a study, undertaken on behalf of the proponent, has shown that the aquifer intersected during the extraction of the coal sample is unconnected to the Pages River.

(3) The Department of the Environment and Heritage has been advised by the NSW Department of Mineral Resources that the Bickham Coal Company has prepared a Review of Environmental Factors under NSW legislative requirements. On November 21 the NSW Minister for Mineral Resources, the Hon Edward Obeid OAM MLC, announced that additional information regarding the impact of the proposal and issues relating to the plan to bulk sample coal is required and that this additional information will be made available for community consultation.

Planning NSW has advised that, should sampling indicate that there is an economic resource, and commercial scale mining be considered, the proposal to mine will undergo a State environmental assessment process at the Environmental Impact Statement level with the Minister for Planning as the consent authority.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: (3) (a) One. (b) Saab Bofors Dynamic AB.

(5) (a) Defence does not publicly release the exact level of project approval as it may weaken the Commonwealth's negotiating position and in some cases may reveal information about capability levels. Public documents indicate the project approval costs as a range of $100-150m. (b) There has been no real change to the project cost. (c) Consistent with long-standing practice, Defence adjusts its project approvals annually for price and exchange variations.
(6) (a) The target completion date is 2006. (b) Yes.

(7) (a) Yes. (b) The options were: first, to extend the life of the in-service equipment (Rapier); second, remove Rapier from service and; third, acquire additional RBS 70 systems to replace Rapier. (c) The first was considered to involve significant cost and risk and offered little capability advantage over acquiring additional RBS 70 systems. The second left a capability gap which was unacceptable to the Government. The third was the preferred alternative as it offered operational, training and logistic benefits, and reduced through life costs due to commonality with the existing in-service RBS 70.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 November 2002:

quote.para: With reference to the LAND 19 project in the Defence Capability Plan:

(2) Project Land 19 and Phase descriptions are as follows:

(b) The end date for the project as a whole is related to completion of the last Phase. This is 2006, noting that this date will be clarified at contract signature when industry confirms what it is able to achieve.

(4) For incomplete projects Defence does not publicly release the exact level of project approval as it may weaken the Commonwealth's negotiating position and in some cases may reveal information about capability levels. Public documents indicate the project approval costs as a range. Once a contract has been signed, the exact contract value is listed in the Commonwealth Gazette. Once a project is completed the total cost can generally be made public. The following information provides the project cost estimate at the time of project approval, expressed as a range for phases not yet completed.

Less than $10m. Phase not complete, currently engaging in tender evaluation.

(b) Refer to Part (3) (b).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 November 2002:

question.para: With reference to page 299 of the Department of Defence annual report for 2001-02, which notes that the Review of Australian Defence Force Remuneration 2001 (the `Nunn Review') was delivered to the Ministers for Defence and Finance and Administration at the end of August 2001 and that a submission setting out the Department of Defence's response to the review recommendations was forwarded to the Minister for Defence on 30 April 2002:
(1) Can a copy of the submission, setting out the department's response to the Nunn Review recommendations, be provided.
(2) Has the Government made any response to any of the recommendations of the Nunn Review; if so: (a) what recommendations have been responded to; and (b) what was the response; if not, why not.
(3) Does the Government still plan to formally respond to the recommendations of the Nunn Review; if so, when will this occur; if not, why not.

(4) (a) Does the Government's delay in responding to the Nunn Review have implications for the long-standing Australian Defence Force (ADF) pay structure review; and (b) does the Government still expect the department to deliver the first phase of this review late in the 2002-03 financial year.

(5) Has a new ADF Enterprise Productivity Arrangement been negotiated; if so: (a) does the new arrangement include any changes recommended by the Nunn Review; and (b) can a copy of the new arrangement be provided.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) No. The department's submission is still being considered.
(2) No. The Nunn Review recommendations are still being considered by the Government.
(3) Yes. The Government will respond when the recommendations have been fully considered.

(4) (a) No. The Nunn Review and the current initiatives being progressed on ADF Pay have been kept as separate matters. Work is continuing on the ADF Pay Structure Review, now known as the Remuneration Reform Project.

(b) The first phase of the Remuneration Reform Project may be deliverable in the later part of this financial year. However, this will largely depend upon the outcomes of deliberations by the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal in February 2003.
(5) Yes. The ADF Workplace Remuneration Arrangement 2002-04 replaced the previous ADF Enterprise Productivity Arrangement 1999-2002 with effect from 7 November 2002:

(a) The new arrangement is consistent with the Nunn Review recommendations. It focuses primarily on broad level pay outcomes and anticipated Defence reform, productivity and performance requirements. The new arrangement does foreshadow expected developments in connection with the ADF Remuneration Reform Project.
(b) The document is available at: http://www.defence.gov.au/dpe/dsa

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 November 2002:

quote.para: With reference to the JP 117 project in the Defence Capability Plan (DCP):

(1) Is JP 117 still an `unapproved project', as listed on the Defence Materiel Organisation (DMO) Internet site; if so, why is this the case and when is it expected that the project will be approved; if not, when was the project approved and what is the project timetable.
(2) Can a description of all the phases of this project be provided.
(3) What was the original timeline for the completion of the project, including the dates for all phases in the project, and when was it due to be completed.
(4) What was the original budget for this project, including the budget for all phases in the project.
(5) What is the current schedule for the completion of this project, including the dates for all phases in the project and when is it due to be completed.

(6) Given that the 2001 DCP estimates that expenditure on JP 117 Phase 2 will be $250-$350 million and the 2002 DCP supplement estimates that expenditure on JP 117 Phase 2 will be $350-$450 million: (a) Why was the funding estimate revised upwards by $100 million; and (b) What is the current estimate of expenditure of JP 117 Phase 2.

(7) The answer to question on notice no. 280 (Senate Hansard, 27 August 2002, p. 3035) stated that the Army is equipped with ground-based air defence weapon systems (GBADWS) Rapier and RBS 70; What are the limitations of these systems.
(8) The answer to question on notice no. 280 indicated that the end-of-life of the Rapier system would occur in 2005; Is this still the case.
(9) Will any capability be lost once the Rapier system is removed from service in 2005 and the RBS 70 system is the sole GBADWS until the next system is acquired under JP 117 Phase 2 in 2009.

(10) Given the limitations of the RBS 70 system, why was it decided to maintain the RBS 70 system as the sole GBADWS between 2005 and 2009, rather than acquire a new system once the Rapier system is removed from service in 2005.
(11) Were any alternatives to maintaining the RBS 70 system as the sole GBADWS between 2005 and 2009 considered; if so, why were the alternatives rejected; if not, why not.

(12) (a) When is it expected that JP 117 Phase 2 will commence; and (b) is the in-service delivery date of 2009 listed in the DCP and the response to question on notice 280 of 24 April 2002 still current.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) JP 117 Phase 1 was approved in 1996 (then as Land 117) but was reviewed and redirected around 1998 to reflect an increased joint focus as part of the total Australian Defence Force (ADF) air defence capability. JP 117 Phase 2 remains unapproved. JP 117 Phase 1 will provide the necessary information to allow the Government to make an informed decision on Phase 2 at 2nd Pass Approval, which is currently planned to occur in FY 04/05.

(2) JP 117 Phase 1 is a Project Definition Study (PDS) being conducted to determine robust costing and capability information required for Government to consider project approval. JP 117 Phase 2 is the acquisition phase of the project.
(3) When Phase 1 was approved in 1996 (as Land Project 117) the in-service date for JP117 was, for planning purposes, 2002.
(4) The budget for Phase 1 on approval in 1996 was $3.760m (December 1996 prices). At the time Phase 1 was approved the provision for Phase 2 was $822.72m (December 1996 prices).

(5) The initial market survey element of JP 117 Phase 1 was completed in 1998. The further definition work necessary to update cost estimates and define technical solutions to provide a basis for Government consideration of Phase 2 is targeted to be complete by the third quarter of 2004. Subject to the outcome of Phase 1, Phase 2 is planned to be complete by the end of 2010.

(6) (a) The funding estimate was not revised upwards by $100m between the 2001 and the 2002 DCP supplement. The project funding estimate was adjusted in line with the global price and exchange adjustment, which placed it in the next costing band in the unclassified 2002 DCP supplement. (b) The current estimate for the expenditure for JP 117 is being examined as part of the annual DCP review process and will be refined throughout the Phase 1 Project Definition Study. The level agreed by Government will reflect judgements about the performance level and basis of provisioning appropriate to our current strategic circumstances.

(7) Rapier and RBS are Short Range Air Defence Weapon Systems optimised for use against low flying aircraft. Longer range and higher level engagement of targets would need to be undertaken by other elements of the ADF air defence capability, such as fighter aircraft.
(8) Yes, current planning is still based on 2005.

(9) RBS70 has for some time been the GBAD system of choice deployed to support ADF operations. Given that the RBS 70 and Rapier are broadly similar in capability the withdrawal of Rapier will not represent a real capability reduction, noting that additional RBS70 systems are being acquired to equip four Air Defence Troops.

(10) The RBS70 is only one part of the total ADF air defence capability, which is very substantial in regional terms. The reason for planning the introduction of a new system under JP117 is not to address current shortfalls in RBS70, but to ensure that the total ADF air defence capability grows to meet emerging challenges.
(11) Yes. Alternatives were considered and rejected on the basis that they were assessed as offering less value for money and higher risk than acquiring additional RBS 70 systems.

(12) (a) The current target date is FY 04/05, subject to the outcome of the current DCP review by the Government. (b) Based on a FY 04/05 decision on Phase 2, the current target in-service delivery date remains around 2009, with project completion around 2010. These dates will be clarified following completion of Phase 1.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 November 2002:

quote.para: With reference to the LAND 19 Phase 5A project in the Defence Capability Plan:
(1) When did the Government grant approval for this project.
(2) (a) When was the request for tender issued; and (b) what was the closing date for tenders.
(3) (a) How many tenders were submitted; and (b) which organisation submitted tenders.
(4) (a) When was the preferred tenderer selected; and (b) when was the contract signed.
(5) (a) What was the budget for this project at the time approval was granted; and (b) has the budget changed since approval was granted; if so, what is the current budget.
(6) What is the completion date for this project and is this still the expected completion date.
(7) When did the RBS 70 system enter service and when was the end-of-life for the RBS 70 system originally due to occur.
(8) When will the end-of-life for the RBS 70 system occur following the life-of-type extension under this project.
(9) (a) Were any options apart from a life-of-type extension considered; (b) what were the options; and (c) why was it decided to proceed with a life-of-type extension and not the other options.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: (3) (a) One. (b) Saab Bofors Dynamic AB.
(4) (a) Tender evaluation is not yet complete. (b) Contract not yet signed.

(5) (a) Defence does not publicly release the exact level of project approval as it may weaken the Commonwealth's negotiating position and in some cases may reveal information about capability levels. Public documents indicate the project approval costs as a range of less than $10m. (b) Consistent with long-standing practice Defence adjusts its project approvals annually for price and exchange variations. There has been no real change to the cost of this project.
(6) (a) The target completion date is 2006. (b) Yes.
(7) The RBS 70 system entered service in 1987 and was originally planned to end life in 2005.
(8) The estimated new end of life is 2015.

(9) (a) No. There is a requirement to remove an ozone depleting substance from the weapons sight and a need to modify the weapon so that it can fire the new generation missile. (b) Not applicable. (c) Not applicable.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 27 November 2002:

quote.para: (1) Will the Minister state whether the Australian Navy or other Navies using Australian waters are deploying low frequency active sonar.
(2) What is the Federal Government's position on the deployment of low frequency active sonar in Australian waters?

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:

quote.para: (1) Neither the Royal Australian Navy (RAN) nor the navies of other nations are deploying such systems within the Australian Economic Exclusion Zone.

(2) The RAN has no plans to deploy low frequency active sonar systems. Changes to the threat scenario facing Australian shipping and trade routes are kept under constant review. If a threat to Australia's security is identified that would require the Australian forces to use any advanced technology that might have a significant impact on the environment, then the implementation of that technology would need to be considered in the context of the provisions of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 27 November 2002:

question.para: Will the Minister introduce legislation for a protocol which requires, where possible, all stranded cetaceans to be necropsied with particular attention paid to the ears and lungs so that sonar causes can be eliminated or proven.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The majority of whale strandings occur in state and territory coastal waters and the Commonwealth therefore does not have jurisdiction to legislate in relation to those strandings. I understand that many States and Territories have adopted Contingency Plans to deal with stranded whales and dolphins.

The Government has however funded research into cetacean stranding. Funding from the Natural Heritage Trust was provided to a project undertaken by Karen Evans examining Cetacean Strandings in the Southern Ocean Sanctuary between 1997 and 2000. The Government contributed $18,500 in funding in the 1998/99 financial year and $12,000 in funding in the 1999/2000 financial year towards the project. The funding has enabled the commencement of analysis of samples collected from cetacean strandings on the Tasmanian coastline, specifically those associated with three mass strandings of sperm whales. In particular, the study has focused on the threat of pollution to cetaceans and has investigated the levels of organochlorines in southern Australian sperm whales. Results indicated that overall concentrations of pollutants appeared to be higher than those previously published in this species in the Southern Hemisphere.

In addition, the Government provided $74,800 in Natural Heritage Trust funding in the 1999/2000 financial year for the construction of four whale rescue trailers for use along the Tasmanian coastline, which have been used to transport whales to Hobart for necropsy purposes.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 27 November 2002:

question.para: (1) Are veterans and war widows still entitled to access the Respite Care Program administered by the Department of Health and Ageing; if so: (a) for each quarter in the past 3 years, how many veterans and widows used that program; and (b) what was the annual cost.

(2) For each quarter of each of the 2001-02 financial year and the 2002-03 financial year to date: (a) how many veterans and widows received respite care from the Veterans' Home Care (VHC) Scheme; and (b) what was the cost per quarter.
(3) How many veterans and widows have transferred from respite care services provided under the VHC to the Health and Ageing Respite Care Program.
(4) What are the existing guidelines for respite care as to which program, either VHC or Health and Ageing, veterans' respite care is to be charged to.

(5) (a) For each quarter in the past 3 years, how many veterans and widows received services provided by the Community Nursing Program of the Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA); and (b) what was the annual cost.
(6) In each quarter of the past 2 years, how many veterans have been transferred from VHC personal care to DVA's Community Nursing Program.

(7) (a) What is the source of the $6 million additional funding for providers with respect to respite care and community nursing, announced in the Minister's media release of 4 November 2002; and (b) is it part of the $8 million additional spending estimated for the 2002-03 financial year, or is it an estimate of increased usage from the pre-existing standing appropriation for community nursing.
(8) Where is this $6 million shown in the DVA Estimates.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) and (b) The Department of Health and Ageing have advised that:
Â· veterans and war widows are entitled to access the National Respite for Carers Program that is funded by the Department of Health and Ageing;

Â· currently data on the number of veteran and war widow clients receiving in-house or emergency respite are not available. In future years, for clients referred from Commonwealth Carer Respite Centres, this information will be available through the National Respite for Carers Program Minimum Data Set and Reporting System, which is in the early implementation stage; and

Â· the number of subsidised veterans and war widows using aged care residential respite for the 13 quarters from 1 July 1999 to 30 September 2002 averaged 686 a quarter and cost the Government some $125,000 a quarter. This averages some $500,000 annually.
(2) (a) The number of veterans and war widows who received in-home and emergency respite in each quarter of 2001-02, and 2002-03 financial year to date, are as follows:

Note: This data is correct as of 25 November 2002. Since numbers of veterans receiving service is derived from the claims submitted by the service providers, the data is only as up to date as the claims.
(b) The costs per quarter for respite for 2001-02, and 2002-03 financial year to date, are as follows:
* Relates to payment of Daily care.
^ Data not yet complete for this quarter.
(3) Nil.

Veterans who are eligible for respite through the Veterans' Home Care (VHC), and are assessed as needing respite, can access up to a maximum of 196 hours of respite care per financial year. This respite can be utilised as in-home or residential respite care, or a combination of both. Residential respite is usually provided in a Commonwealth accredited residential care facility.

Veterans requiring more residential respite than 196 hours or 28 days, can access a further 35 days through the Department of Health and Ageing respite program but the veteran would be required to pay the daily care fee for that period.

(4) The Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) will pay for a maximum of 196 hours of in home, or residential respite, or a combination of both, for veterans approved through VHC. Veterans requiring additional residential respite, above the 196 hours will be required to pay the daily care fee themselves.
(5) (a) The number of veterans and war widows who were provided with community nursing services through the Community Nursing Program in the last 3 years, as identified by quarter, is as follows:

(b) The annual cost for the provision of community nursing services through the Community Nursing Program for the last 3 years is $48,131,439.65 for the 1999-2000 financial year, $51,479,357.26 for the 2000-2001 financial year and $52,996,390.35 for the 2001-2002 financial year.

(6) No veterans transferred from VHC to Community Nursing. It is a seamless service. Veterans may graduate to the Community Nursing program as their levels of Community Nursing needs grow due to increased frailty.

The Community Nursing program provides personal care to veterans who require it as part of a treatment regime or have more complex personal care needs. Under these arrangements, the personal care is delivered by, or under the supervision or, a Registered Nurse, as clinically appropriate.

(7) (a) When the Department of Veterans' Affairs took over responsibility of Home and Community Care (HACC) service for veterans and war widows it undertook to mirror the entire range of service provided under that program. This entails service delivery that ranges over the closely related but separately resourced programs of community nursing and respite care. In reviewing VHC funds' usage over the past year it is estimated that some $6m of VHC operations can more properly be held against the community nursing and respite care programs freeing up VHC funds for use in that specific program.

(b) As explained in (a) above, the $6m is the estimated expenditure under VHC operations that can be apportioned to the current standing appropriation for community nursing and respite care. It is noted that current estimates indicate that expenditure on these programs is expected to remain within the forward estimates for this year. The $6m is additional to the increase of $8m in estimated expenditure under the VHC program in 2002-03.
(8) It is in other health care expenditure under Outcome 2.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 November 2002:

question.para: With reference to the answer to the question on notice no. 240 (Senate Hansard, 19 August 2002, p. 3150) and the tenderfor portable sound projection systems for the Navy:
(1) Can a copy of the request for tender (RFT) be provided.
(2) What was the delivery date specified in the RFT.
(3) Did the RFT specify commercial off-the-shelf equipment.
(4) When was the contract awarded.
(5) Have the required specifications outlined in the RFT been amended in any way.
(6) Does the department have any concerns about the winning tenderer's ability to deliver the required number of units that meet all specifications by March 2003.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. A copy of the RFT has been forwarded separately to your office.
(2) No delivery date was specified in the RFT.
(3) No. However, the RFT contained a definition of the term.

(5) Yes. Amendments have been made to incorporate those options and alternatives in the Preferred Tenderer's offer that have been accepted as useful and to make the specification document a part of the contract. All amendments were of a minor nature, and no significant departure has been made from the original required specifications. A copy has been forwarded separately to your office.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 4 December 2002:

question.para: With reference to the answers to the questions on notice nos 168 (Senate Hansard, 15 May 2002, p. 1654) and 375 (Senate Hansard, 19 August 2002, p. 3226): Given that scientists from the University of Tasmania deny ever having been involved in genetic engineering tree research, does the Minister still consider the above-mentioned answers to be correct.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: The answers provided to questions on notice nos 168 and 375 are based on the records of the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Committee (GMAC). GMAC was not part of the Department of Health and Ageing during the time period to which these records relate. To the best of the Department's knowledge the answers are correct.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, upon notice, on 5 December 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is it the case that seafarers are applying for, and are eligible to be issued with, transit visas to enter Australia to join their ships at an Australian port; if so, how many transit visas have been granted for this purpose in each of the past 10 years.

(2) (a) When were transit visas first introduced; (b) by what legislation and/or regulations were they first introduced; and (c) were seafarers immediately eligible for this visa for the purpose of ship crew changeovers.
(3) Before transit visas were introduced, what visa did seafarers use for ship crew changeovers
(4) (a) What is the stated purpose of transit visas; (b) who is eligible to apply for, or be issued with, a transit visa; and (c) what is the cost of obtaining a transit visa.
(5) What other visa categories are available without an application cost.
(6) What arrangements are in place with the department for seafarers to apply for transit visas.
(7) Are transit visas in an electronic form; if so, how does ACS identify them at the airport for clearance purposes.
(8) How many transit visas have been issued by the department to seafarers in each of the past 10 years.
(9) Are foreign crew leaving Australia by air required to apply for visas upon departure; if so, in what visa category.
(10) Does the department process these applications; if so, what criteria are applied to assess the applications.

(11) (a) What checks, if any, does the department carry out before issuing these transit visas; and (b) does it include a check against the department's Movement Alert List; if not: (i) why not; and (ii) are there any other visas for which these checks are not required.

(12) (a) How do Australian Customs Service (ACS) officers at airports determine that the transit visas are for seafarers; and (b) what additional documentation, if any, are seafarers required to provide to prove that they are joining a ship.

(13) (a) Do the transit visas for this purpose have any conditions; and (b) what, if any, checks are carried out by either the ACS or the department to determine that the conditions of the transit visa have been met.
(14) Do seafarers require passports to apply for transit visas.

(15) (a) What measures, if any, does the department, or any other department or agency, have in place to ensure compliance with the transit visa requirement that seafarers join their ships within 72 hours; and (b) how many times has this requirement been breached in each of the past 10 years.

(16) (a) What is the penalty for breaching the visa requirements; (b) are visas cancelled as a result; if not, why not; and (c) which other visas are exempt from cancellation for breaching the conditions.
(17) (a) What visa category is the seafarer on when they board their ship; and (b) what is the process for receiving that visa.
(18) (a) If a seafarer leaves a ship in an Australian port, what visa is the seafarer on; and (b) how long is the seafarer eligible to be on this visa while away from the ship.

(19) In relation to the Stadacona, which travelled from Melbourne to Brisbane to Port Pirie during May and June 2002, changed crew and remains in Australia: (a) to what place outside Australia, if any, did the Stadacona travel during the course of the above-mentioned voyages from Melbourne to Brisbane to Port Pirie; (b) if the ship did travel to a place outside Australia during the course of that voyage, what visas did the foreign crew working on the ship hold whilst they were in Australia; (c) if the crew did not hold any visas, under what authority were they working during their time in Australia; and (d) are any of the members of that crew still in Australia; if so, what visas do they now hold.

(20) If there are foreign crew in Australia on such vessels as outlined above: (a) what visas do they hold; (b) under what authority are they working in Australia; and (c) are they monitored by the ACS; if not, how does the department determine that the visa conditions have been met.
(21) Does the department consider the foreign vessels trading between Australian ports using Single Voyage Permits or Continuous Voyage Permits as actually being engaged in international voyages.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) Yes, seafarers may apply for a transit visa to join their ship, and providing they meet the criteria for the grant of a transit visa as set out in the Migration Regulations, will be eligible.

The table below shows the total number of transit visas granted since 1994/95 (earlier data is not available). The figures include transit visas granted to persons wishing to transit Australia to another country as well as seafarers joining their ship. I do not have a breakdown of the data.

(2) (a) and (b) Transit visas were prescribed by legislation in the Migration Regulations 1989, although the transit visa regime existed in one form or another prior to these Regulations coming into effect. (c) Prior to the commencement of the Migration Regulations 1989, seafarers were able to access transit visas for ship crew changeovers. Their eligibility for the visa would be assessed against the criteria or policy that existed at the time.

(3) A transit visa regime has existed in one form or another since Australia introduced migration controls. Prior to the existence of the current transit visa, seafarers accessed transhipment visas or endorsements for ship crew changeovers.

(4) (a) Transit visas are temporary visas permitting the holder to travel to and enter Australia on one or more occasions and to remain in Australia no longer than 72 hours on each occasion. The visa is granted to persons intending to enter Australia :
(i) to pass through Australia in transit to another country; or
(ii) to pass through Australia in order to join a non-military ship as a member of its crew.

(b) All non-citizens are eligible to apply for transit visas. A transit visa will be granted if all the criteria set out in the Migration Regulations are met. (c) There is no cost involved in lodging an application for a transit visa.

(5) Several other visa categories do not attract a visa application charge. These include, but are not limited to, certain ETAs, certain student visas, certain bridging visas, border visas, emergency visas, confirmatory visas and offshore humanitarian program visas.
(6) Seafarers requiring a transit visa may apply at the nearest Australian High Commission or Embassy.
(7) Transit visas are electronically recorded. The evidence of the visa is provided as a paper label affixed to their passport. They can be identified on arrival at an airport by the visa label.
(8) Please note my answer to question 1.

(9) No. Foreign crew signing off their vessel for repatriation by air will have a âsign-offâ stamp placed in their passport by the Customs clearance officer as they leave their ship. This identifies them as departing crew at the airport on departure. They continue to hold their Special Purpose Visa for the period specified in the maintenance letter signed by the master of the vessel (to a maximum of 30 days).
(10) Not applicable, see answer to 9 above.

(11) (a) and (b) All applicants for transit visas are checked against DIMIA's Movements Alert List, and nationals of selected countries are further checked for security purposes. In addition, checks are made that the applicant is a genuine seaman seeking to join a ship in Australia as a member of crew.

(12) (a) On arrival in Australia, seafarers must present their transit visa as evidenced in their travel document, and complete an incoming passenger card. (b) When applying for a transit visa and on arrival in Australia by air, it is a legislative requirement that seafarers present a valid passport or seafarer's identity document. Further, it is a policy requirement that on application and on arrival at an airport the seafarer also present the following details as provided by the shipping agent: the names of the persons joining the vessel as crew; the names of the persons they are replacing; the name of the vessel; the date of arrival in Australia of the persons to be visaed; the port and date they are expected to join the vessel; and if they are not the vessel's owner, a copy of the request for crew from the vessel's agent in Australia which contains the details of the crew members applying for visas.
(13)(a) The following conditions apply to all transit visas:

answer.para: Â· The holder must enter on or before the date specified by the Minister for the purpose and
Â· Conditions 8101 (the holder must not engage in work in Australia) and 8201 (while in Australia the holder must not engage, for more than 3 months, in any studies or training).

Any one or more of conditions 8501, 8514 and 8516 may also be imposed. Condition 8501 requires that the holder must maintain adequate arrangements for health insurance while the holder is in Australia. Condition 8514 states that during the visa period of the visa, there must be no material change in the circumstances on the basis of which it was granted. Condition 8516 states that the holder must continue to be a person who would satisfy the primary or secondary criteria, as the case requires, for the grant of the visa.

quote.para: (b) There are no specific checks made to ensure that the conditions of a transit visa are met. As with all other visa holders, a transit visa holder may be subject to questioning by immigration airport staff on entry or by immigration compliance staff after entry if there is a reason to believe that the holder may not be complying with the conditions of his/her visa.
(14) No. Under current legislation transit visas can be evidenced in Seafarer's Identity Documents when the holder is travelling to Australia to join their vessel.

(15) (a) There are no specific measures to ensure seafarers join their ship within the validity of their transit visa. As with all visa holders, if seafarers overstay the validity of their visa they become unlawful non-citizens liable for detention and removal. (b) My Department does not maintain separate statistics on how many seafarers fall into this category.
(16) (a) and (b) If any of the visa conditions are breached, the visa may be liable for cancellation. (c) Not applicable.

(17) (a) Seafarers may first arrive in Australia by air as holders of transit visas. They then have 72 hours to sign-on to their vessel, at which time they are taken to hold a Special Purpose Visa by operation of law. Australian Customs Service (ACS) Officers attend vessels where such a crew change occurs to verify the seafarer's identity and ensure his or her details appear on the crew manifest. (b) a Special Purpose Visa is granted by operation of law.

(18) (a) and (b) If a seafarer leaves their ship in an Australian port without the permission of the master of the vessel they are considered to be a deserter and their Special Purpose Visa ceases at midnight of the day on which they desert. If a seafarer permanently leaves their ship in an Australian port with the permission of the master they continue to hold their Special Purpose Visa for the period specified in the maintenance letter signed by the master (to a maximum of 30 days). If such a seafarer wishes to remain longer in Australia for tourism or other purposes, they are required to apply for the appropriate visa.

(19) (a) The Department of Transport and Regional Services has advised that the CSL Stadacona did not complete a Melbourne-Brisbane-Port Pirie voyage in May or June this year. (b) Not applicable. (c) During May and June this year the Stadacona was Australian crewed. (d) I am not able to advise if the crew are still in Australia.

(20) (a) Foreign crew working on vessels in Australian waters generally hold Special Purpose Visas; (b) The Special Purpose Visa is the authority under which they would be working in Australia; (c) The Australian Customs Service monitors ships operating in Australian waters.

(21) This would depend on the circumstances of an individual vessel. In general vessels that hold either a Single Voyage Permit or a Continuing Voyage Permit are considered to be international vessels. However, whether the vessel is considered to be one on an international voyage would depend upon the details of that vessels voyage pattern.

subdebateinfo.title: Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Legislation: Community Consultation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 992)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 5 December 2002:

question.para: With reference to the answer to question on notice no.864 (Senate Hansard, 3 December 2002, p. 6713) concerning consultation on the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999: What is the total budgeted cost of the 12-month, full-time position at the National Farmers' Federation that commenced on 19 November 2002.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The budgeted cost of the position is $110,239.04 plus associated minor costs in relation to printing of information about the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 5 December 2002:

question.para: Will Federal funding: (a) for the Cities for Climate Protection Program; and (b) to support Local Agenda 21 planning, be provided after the 2002-03 financial year; if not, why not; if so, will this funding be less than, equal to, or more than the funding for the 2002-03 financial year.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The Government recognises that local governments have a vital role in our national greenhouse response, due to the unique way that they deliver services, interact with, and influence people at a local level. Councils in Australia have a direct impact on emissions through their own activities, and a major role in influencing the practices of businesses, industries and households within their jurisdictions.

Australian local governments are among the most proactive in the world. Cities for Climate Protectionâ¢ (CCPâ¢) Australia now has 162 local governments representing some 65% of the Australian population. This also represents 30% of local government members worldwide.

(a) CCPâ¢ has the strong support of the Government and we look forward to the continued success of the program. Decisions about the forward funding of lapsing programs will be taken in the Budget context and announced at that time.
(b) Federal funding currently supports Local Agenda 21 planning. The matter of support for the program after 2002-2003 is at present subject to budget considerations.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 December 2002:

quote.para: Will a `lessons learnt' report on the Australian defence and emergency management authorities immediate response to the Bali bombings be compiled; if so: (a) will this report be made public; and (b) when will this report be completed.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes. The Government has already announced that there will be a review of the response to the Bali bombings. That review will examine, inter alia, the defence and emergency management authorities immediate response. (a) Any decision on public distribution will be made once the review has been completed. (b) The review will be conducted in early 2003.

subdebateinfo.title: Environment: Passenger Vehicle Liquid Petroleum Gas Tanks
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 997)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 5 December 2002:

question.para: (1) Why is it that passenger vehicles in Australia are currently not manufactured with liquid petroleum gas (LPG) tanks replacing conventional petrol tanks.

(2) Would the sale of passenger vehicles manufactured with 100 per cent LPG tanks offset greenhouse gases that are escalating in Australia; if so, when will the Federal Government implement a directive for this to occur.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) There are vehicles manufactured in Australia fitted with LPG fuel tanks. Ford, Holden and Mitsubishi are manufacturing vehicles fitted with LPG tanks and Toyota will manufacture such a vehicle in near future. The extent to which these vehicles are manufactured in Australia is dictated by the commercial decisions of Australian motor vehicle producers.

(2) A paper published in 2002 by the Australian Liquefied Petroleum Gas Association `Liquefied Petroleum Gas as an Automotive Fuel' indicates that LPG powered cars have lower emissions of greenhouse gases than equivalent vehicles using conventional fuel. The level of reduction varies according to the technology employed. The Government supports uptake of LPG powered vehicles through exempting LPG from excise.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 6 December 2002:

question.para: Given that, according to the foreword and annexes of the new Radiation Protection Standard RPS3 - Maximum Exposure Levels to Radiofrequency Fields - 3 kHz to 300 GHz, approved by Dr John Loy on 7 May 2002, research papers indicate adverse health problems from extremely low levels of radiofrequency (RF) energy, which have neither been confirmed nor denied:
(1) How will the Australian Communications Authority (ACA) handle these uncertainties when it integrates the levels specified in the standard into the regulatory framework.

(2) Will there be references in the regulations to: (a) the research papers; (b) the precautionary measures contained in clause 5.7(e) of the standard; and (c) the annexes at the back of the standard.
(3) Why has the ACA used only selected parts of the RF standard in regulating the mobile phone and broadcasting industries.
(4) What protection is now offered regarding occupational exposure to workers in these industries since the sections relating to occupational exposure have not been taken up by ACA.
(5) Why did the Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency agree to selective use of parts of the standard.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) to (4) These parts of the question should be addressed to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, as the Minister responsible for the Australian Communications Authority (ACA).

(5) The ACA proposes to change the Radiocommunications (Electromagnetic Radiation - Human Exposure) Standard 2001, made under section 162 of the Radiocommunications Act 1992, to incorporate the limits of the new Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency (ARPANSA) Radiation Protection Standard.

The Radiocommunications Standard 2001 regulates the performance of particular radiocommunications transmitters to protect the health and safety of persons exposed to electromagnetic radiation from the transmitters. ARPANSA agreed to selective use of parts of the ARPANSA Standard, as it would be inappropriate to insert, for example, sections relating to detailed personal protection considerations when the object of the Standard is equipment performance.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 9 December 2002:

question.para: (1) Given that Lake Cowal in central-western New South Wales is included in the Register of the National Estates because of its natural significance is also worthy of Ramsar Convention on Wetlands listing and is included in the Directory of Important Wetlands of Australia: Will Lake Cowal be included in the proposed `National List' under the new heritage legislation and afforded Commonwealth protection; if not, why not.

(2) Given that the proposed Cowal Gold Project will be built in the middle of Lake Cowal, which is one of Australia's most important wetlands and habitats for international migratory birds: How can Australia meet its international obligations under such agreements as the Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals (the Bonn Convention), the Convention on Biological Diversity, China-Australia Migratory Bird Agreement and Japan-Australia Migratory Bird Agreement, when this project goes ahead.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The proposed amendments to the Environment Protection & Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999, which will establish a National Heritage List, are still before Parliament. In their present form the Bills allow for a place to be nominated by a member of the public, the yet to be established Australian Heritage Council or the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. In any case, the place is required to undergo a rigorous assessment against national heritage significance criteria and be subject to public comment. After completion of this process, inclusion on the National Heritage List is a matter for the Minister's decision. While Lake Cowal is included on the Register of the National Estate no assessment of its relative significance at a national scale has been attempted. It is therefore not possible to say whether or not Lake Cowal will be included in the proposed National Heritage List.

(2) Migratory birds listed under the Convention on the Conservation of Migratory Species of Wild Animals (the Bonn Convention), the China-Australia Migratory Bird Agreement (CAMBA) and Japan-Australia Migratory Bird Agreement (JAMBA) are protected under the provisions of the Environment Protection & Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999. Any action that has, may have, or is likely to have a significant impact on listed migratory species must be referred to the Commonwealth Environment Minister. The Lake Cowal Gold Project was referred to the Minister on 29 August 2001 and was determined to be a not controlled action on 29 September 2001.

The Lake Cowal proposal has been subject to a rigorous State Environmental Impact Assessment process (EIS), which addresses the issues of waterbirds and ensures the protection of important habitat for waterbirds.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 9 December 2002:

question.para: (1) Who proposed the federal funding of the West Wyalong - Lake Cowal road.
(2) Has the government had any contact with the Lake Cowal mine developers about the road.

(3) (a) Why is a federally-funded road being built between West Wyalong and Lake Cowal when other roads in the area will remain as gravel roads; (b) does this mean that the Federal Government is supporting the Lake Cowal gold mine proposal through the back door.

(4) Can the Minister assure the Parliament, and the people of the Murray-Darling Basin, that a major toxic release from the proposed Lake Cowal gold project, for example, of cyanide or arsenic, would not harm humans and the environment.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Bland Shire Council.
(2) I am advised that neither my Department nor the Department of Transport and Regional Services has had any contact with the Lake Cowal mine developers about the road.

(3) (a) Bland Shire Council has advised that the upgrading work on the West Wyalong to Lake Cowal Road is in response to the requirements of the wheat growing communities serviced by this road; (b) No.

(4) The proposed gold mine at Lake Cowal was referred under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (the Act) on 29 August 2001. It was determined not to be a controlled action on 29 September 2001 as it was not considered likely to have a significant impact on any matter protected under the Act. The NSW Department of Mineral Resources has stated that a nil discharge (of process waters) policy will be enforced and that cyanide levels in the tailings facilities will be kept at levels that are considered non-toxic to birds.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 10 December 2002:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware that Mr Roger Bennetts, a representative of the Canadian gold mining company, Barrick Gold, which holds exploration licences at Lake Cowal, has admitted in the NSW Land and Environment Court that the company is carrying out exploration work without water licences and without a development consent for a slurry pit on Lot 23.

(2) Is the Minister aware that, although the company says it is trucking in water from West Wyalong, there appears to be evidence that the company is also taking water from a monitor bore on Lot 23 for which it has sought a licence but which has so far not been granted.
(3) Is the company's action consistent with Federal Government requirements; and if not, what action will be taken.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) No
(2) No

(3) The proposed gold mine at Lake Cowal (NSW) was referred to the Commonwealth under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 on 29 August 2001. It was determined not to be a `controlled action' on 29 September 2001.

The management of water resources at the mine site, including the licensing of use and disposal, is the responsibility of the NSW Government. The issues raised should therefore be taken up with that government.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 9 December 2002:

question.para: (1) How can the Commonwealth Government justify allowing a gold mine to go ahead at Lake Cowal in the Murray-Darling Basin when the area is in a severe drought, and local farmers require water for agriculture and domestic purposes.
(2) Is the Minister aware that the mine will use between 4 and 14 megalitres of water per day taken from a borefield north-east of the lake when operational, which is expected to be in 2005.

(3) Is the Minister aware that a Wiradjuri sacred site is being desecrated by the Barrick Gold Corporation at Lake Cowal, and is in danger of total destruction now that a National Parks and Wildlife Service section 90 Consent to Destroy has been issued.

(4) What is the Minister doing to issue an emergency declaration under section 9 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984 to stop desecration of this highly significant Aboriginal place.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The proposed gold mine at Lake Cowal (NSW) was referred under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 on 29 August 2001. It was determined not to be a controlled action on 29 September 2001.

(2) The management of water resources at the mine site, including the licensing of use, is the responsibility of the NSW Government. The issues raised should therefore be taken up with that government.

(3) The Minister is aware that the gold mining area at Lake Cowal is alleged to be significant to Wiradjuri people and that the NSW National Parks and Wildlife Service has issued a Consent to Destroy.

(4) The Minister has considered an application under section 9 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984 for protection from threat of injury or desecration of the Cowal Gold Project area, but has declined to make a declaration as he was not satisfied that the area specified by the applicant is of particular significance to Aboriginal people within the meaning of the Act.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 10 December 2002:

question.para: (1) Of the calls made to the Regional Law Hotline from October 2001 to January 2002, how many were: (a) calls in relation to queries on Family Tax Benefit A and B debt advices received during this period; (b) calls on Centrelink issues directly relating to Family Tax Benefit A and/or B; and (c) handled to the satisfaction of the customer.
(2) (a) What method is used to determine if a customer is satisfied; and (b) what happened to those people who were not satisfied with the response given by the staff of the hotline.
(3) How many calls were referred to the closest debt recovery section for clarification of the debt.
(4) What was the maximum and minimum average duration of the calls for this specific period.
(5) What is the funding formula that Centrelink used to justify its reduction of expenditure on the hotline by $851 107 for the 2002-03 financial year.
(6) Who is most likely to be affected by this reduction in funding.
(7) Can the method used for determining the amount of funding required by Centrelink to respond to queries for the Australian Law Online be provided; if not, why not.

(8) Will any funding deficits in Centrelink's expenditure for the 2002-03 Regional Law Hotline be adjusted throughout the financial year; if not, why not; if so: (a) at what point will the funding be adjusted; (b) how will this be assessed; and (c) where will it come from.

talk.start.para: âThe Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Centrelink provides separate daily counts of calls made to the Regional and Family Law Hotlines. However, Centrelink customer service officers are not able to directly distinguish between calls made to the Regional Law Hotline and calls made to the Family Law Hotline when they record detailed information about the calls they answer as calls from both hotline numbers are channelled through a single processing queue. To identify whether or not a caller is eligible to receive the enhanced Regional Law Hotline service each caller is asked to provide their postcode. If the postcode is supplied it is entered into an online system which automatically notifies the customer service officer of a match against a list of designated Regional Law Hotline postcodes.

From 1 October 2001 to 31 January 2002 a total of 193 calls were recorded as being made to either the Family or Regional Law Hotlines from Regional Law Hotline designated postcodes. Of these calls: (a) none were recorded to specifically relate to queries on Family Tax Benefit A and B debt advices; (b) none were recorded to specifically relate to Centrelink issues directly relating to Family Tax Benefit A or B, although 33 calls were recorded as seeking non specified general information or legal advice or other non specified assistance; and (c) all but one call was handled to the satisfaction of the caller.

(2) (a) Callers are asked to indicate the level of satisfaction with the service they have received at the end of each call. Centrelink customer service officers check one or more check boxes to indicate the level of caller satisfaction on an electronic form at the end of each call. Where a caller is dissatisfied the reason is also recorded in a free text field on the electronic form. (b) The caller who expressed dissatisfaction was unable to accept that legal advice was unavailable to her at 7 pm. No further action was taken in this particular case.
(3) No calls were recorded as being referred for clarification of a debt.
(4) For the period 1 October 2001 to 31 January 2002 the maximum and minimum average duration of calls to the Regional and Family Law Hotlines were 9.8 and 5.2 minutes respectively.

(5) The difference between the actual expenditure in 2001-02 and the estimated expenditure for 2002-03 for the Centrelink call centre service is due to a fall in the average daily customer service officer sign-on hours.

The Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with Centrelink which governs the operation of the Regional and Family Law Hotline call centres makes provision for call centre staffing levels to be adjusted periodically to reflect actual call volumes. The MOU also provides for a service level that requires 80% of calls to be answered within 30 seconds.

Initially the Attorney-General's Department asked for enough staff to handle 250,000 calls per year. However this estimate was higher than the actual number of calls received. The call centre staffing level has been progressively adjusted to reflect the actual number of calls being made. Staffing levels have been progressively reduced from 193 sign-on hours per day in June 2001 to 42 in September 2002. As a consequence of this adjustment the monthly charge from Centrelink for operating the telephone service has fallen from $280,330 in June 2001 to $72,696 in September 2002.

(6) Centrelink has reduced the number of customer service officers in the Regional and Family Law Hotline call centres. The level of service provided to callers has been maintained within the agreed standard as specified in the MOU with Centrelink. Therefore callers should not be adversely affected by the reduction in staffing levels.
(7) The Australian Law Online call centre service is comprised of the Regional and Family Law Hotlines. Payments made to Centrelink are based on the following factors:
(a) the actual Regional and Family Law Hotline call centre customer service officer staffing level measured in sign-on hours; and
(b) the telecommunication costs associated with calls to the toll free Regional and Family Law Hotlines.

(8) The reduction in funding was to match the service to the actual demand - it has not meant a reduction in service to callers. The Department will continue to closely monitor call volumes to ensure that call centre staffing is aligned with actual demand and that the MOU service level is maintained.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 10 December 2002:

question.para: (1) How many offences of the Copyright Act 1968 in relation to piracy have resulted in: (a) a conviction; (b) a maximum penalty fine of $65 000 being imposed; and/or (c) imprisonment.
(2) Can information be provided on individual cases where prosecution of these crimes have led to conviction, financial penalties and/or imprisonment.
(3) In cases where piracy was found to have occurred, what happened to the copying devices used to pirate movies or sound recordings.

(4) In each conviction in relation to piracy of movies or sound recordings, did the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions make a submission on behalf of the Government during the trial or sentencing phase which requested the court to take into consideration the quantity and value of the items seized; if so, what was the court's comment or finding in each case in relation to this submission.

talk.start.para: âThe Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) My answer to Question on Notice 823(1)(a)-(c) remains current.
(2) My answer to Question on Notice 823(2) remains current.
(3) My answer to Question on Notice 823(3) remains current.
(4) My answer to Question on Notice 823(4) remains current .

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 10 December 2002:

question.para: (1) With reference to question on notice no. 744, how many of the successful claims have been brought to the attention of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) and, in particular, the ADF Medical Service.
(2) What proportion of claims accepted were based on diagnoses of private medical practitioners.
(3) How many claims have been rejected.
(4) What is the current fortnightly tax free value of the Total and Permanent Incapacity Pension being paid.
(5) How many accepted claimants are also in receipt of service pension (invalidity).

(6) In the event that the Department of Defence is unaware of the payment of such pensions, to either serving or discharged personnel, is that pension additional to salary and/or superannuation payments.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Department of Veterans' Affairs has not provided the Australian Defence Force with details of any individual who had service in East Timor and who has had a successful application for benefits under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986.

The Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) is bound by the provisions of the Privacy Act 1988. It would contravene the provisions of Information Privacy Principle (IPP) 11 for DVA to routinely provide claim information to the Department of Defence.

(2) The proportion of compensation claims under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 which provided a diagnosis by a private medical practitioner is not known and could only be obtained by an examination of individual files.

(3) 462 individuals who had service in East Timor have had disabilities rejected under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. Some of these disabilities were claimed in respect of other periods of service. Many of those who have rejected disabilities have other disabilities accepted either in respect of East Timor service or other eligible periods of service.
(4) The current amount of the special rate of disability pension (known as the totally and permanently incapacitated rate) is $742.40 per fortnight which is tax free.
(5) 14 individuals who had service in East Timor are now receiving an invalidity service pension. This is not necessarily due to disabilities from service in East Timor.

(6) The special rate of disability pension is payable essentially only where service related incapacity limits the veteran's capacity for work to not more than 8 hours per week. Any salary or wage payments paid in respect of such limited work would have no impact on the payment of special rate pension. Salary payment reflecting any greater work capacity would debar the veteran from receiving special rate pension.
The special rate pension will be reduced by an actuarially determined amount whenever other parties, including Defence, also pay compensation for the same incapacity.
Any superannuation payment would be additional to any disability pension payable under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA).

With respect to invalid service pension or age service pension, income and assets tests apply and any income, assessable under the VEA, will affect the rate of pension payable. Disability pension is excluded from the income test. Periodic superannuation and salary payments are assessable income and would reduce service pension by forty cents for each dollar in excess of the income free area.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 10 December 2002:

question.para: (1) Is the Minister aware that Gippsland Water has proposed to the Victorian State Government that Dutson Downs should be the site for dumping all the toxic waste generated in Victoria.
(2) Is the Minister also aware that the Victorian State Government has indicated it will not require a full Environmental Effect Study of the toxic soils proposal.
(3) Is the Minister aware that the proposed site near Sale in Gippsland is between two Convention on Wetlands (RAMSAR) sites.

(4) Given that, according to the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 website, neither Gippsland Water nor the Victorian State Government, has notified the Minister that this is, or may be, a controlled action under the provisions of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999: (a) is the Minister of the view that the proposed toxic dump and/or the dumping of liquid waste may be, or is, a controlled action; and (b) has the Minister asked that the proposal be referred.
(5) Is the Minister aware that the Victorian State Government has also proposed to bury low-level radioactive waste at Dutson Downs.
(6) Has the Minister been notified by Gippsland Water of this proposal.

(7) Is the Minister aware that large quantities of liquid toxic waste have already been dumped in pools upon which migratory birds swim and that Gippsland Water, in its Expression of Interest, admits that the proposed action has the potential to impact on these RAMSAR sites.
(8) What action does the Minister intend to take with regard to these two matters.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) No. I am advised, however, that Gippsland Water prepared an Expression of Interest to accept and treat contaminated soils as part of the Victorian Government's industrial waste management strategy.
(3) Yes.

(4) (a) The proposal will only require Commonwealth environmental approval if it will or is likely to have a significant impact on a matter of national environmental significance under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 (EPBC Act). The proposal has not been referred to me under the EPBC Act and I am not therefore in a position to respond to the question.
(b) No.

(5) I am advised that Gippsland Water is in the process of obtaining Victorian Government approval for a facility for containment of naturally occurring radioactive material found in by-products of petroleum exploration and production.

(7) I am advised that the No.2 Storage and other artificial treatment ponds at the Dutson Downs Wastewater Treatment Facility attract a number of listed migratory species. The treatment ponds receive domestic and industrial wastewater for treatment prior to discharge via the Delray Beach Ocean Outfall. These ponds are not listed Ramsar sites.

The Gippsland Water Expression of Interest notes that future developments could have an indirect effect on parts of the Gippsland Lakes Ramsar site and may be subject to the EPBC Act. Further preparatory work being undertaken by Gippsland Water for this proposal includes consideration of potential for impacts on Ramsar sites and the requirement for referral under the Act.

(8) An officer of my Department has visited the Dutson Downs site and discussed the potential application of the EPBC Act with Gippsland Water. Should any activity at the facility be likely to have a significant impact on a matter of national environmental significance, I will take action as appropriate to ensure that the requirements of the Act are met.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Science and Training, upon notice, on 12 December 2002:

quote.para: (1) Can the following information be provided in the same format as Table 1 on page 7 of the discussion paper `Setting Firm Foundations', concerning university finance, list the distribution of HECS debts: The number of HECS debtors in each band of debt, arranged by the year in which they most recently incurred a HECS debt.

(2) (a) What is the basis of the projections contained in Table 2.6 on page 82 of the Higher Education Report for the 2002-04 Triennium; (b) what are the projections through to 2010; and (c) what proportion of each category in Table 2.6 is attributable to: (i) past students; (ii) existing students; and (iii) future students.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Education, Science and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) administers HECS repayments. The HECS management information system used by the ATO for this purpose requires specific programming to produce the data requested by the honourable Senator and the task is both complex and time-consuming. The ATO has commenced the programming work required and has advised that the data will be available in late January 2003 and a detailed response to this part of the question will be provided to the honourable Senator at that time.

(2) The HECS forward estimates produced by the Department of Education, Science and Training (DEST) form the basis of the table referred to in part (2) of the honourable Senator's question. The data inputs that drive the forward estimates are as follows:

answer.para: Â· HECS band rates; HECS non-differential rate;
Â· HECS-liable student load;
Â· HECS liabilities amounts - including up-front payments, payments to universities for student loans and the 25 per cent discount for up-front payment;
Â· proportion of HECS students by HECS band and payment option;
Â· Bridging for Overseas Trained Professionals Loans Scheme (BOTPLS) loan amounts;
Â· Postgraduate Education Loan Scheme (PELS) loan amounts;
Â· Open Learning Deferred Payments Scheme (OLDPS) loan amounts; OLDPS basic charge; number of OLDPS units;
Â· voluntary and compulsory (PAYG) repayments of loans;
Â· 15 per cent discount on voluntary repayments;
Â· HECS doubtful debt percentage;
Â· Consumer Price Index (CPI);
Â· Higher Education Operating Grant Index; and
Â· write-downs due to the death of debtors, remission of HECS debts, and refunds of voluntary repayments.

quote.para: Table 2.6 on page 82 of the Higher Education Funding Report for the 2002-04 Triennium provides a summary of HECS liabilities, payments and accumulated debt for the financial years from 1989-90 to 2004-05. The table has been extended below to show financial projections through to 2006 in accordance with the normal Budget Forward Estimates requirements. Projections are not normally prepared for periods beyond the Budget Forward Estimates period as they are considered to be potentially unreliable. Information sought on what proportion of each category in Table 2.6 can be attributed to past, present and future students is unavailable as the data inputs used for the HECS forward estimates is not collected on this basis and therefore can not be split to determine these proportions.
